{{Redirect|Agrahara}}
[[Image:Bhaskararajapuram agraharam.jpg|thumb|right|200px| An ''Agraharam'' in [[Thanjavur District]], [[Tamil Nadu]]]] [[File:Agraharam.jpg|right|thumb|An Agraharam from [[Tirunelveli]] assembled within the [[DakshinaChitra]] museum.]] An '''''Agraharam''''' or '''''Agrahara''''' was a grant of land and royal income from it, typically by a king or a noble family, to religious purposes, particularly to [[Brahmin]]s to maintain temples in that land or a pilgrimage site and to sustain their families.<ref name="Talbot2001p89">{{cite book|author=Cynthia Talbot|title=Precolonial India in Practice: Society, Region, and Identity in Medieval Andhra|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pfAKljlCJq0C|year=2001|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-803123-9|pages=89, 161, 169}}</ref><ref>AA Macdonnell, [http://dsalsrv02.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/app/macdonell_query.py?page=9 A practical Sanskrit dictionary with transliteration, accentuation, and etymological analysis throughout] London: Oxford University Press, page 9</ref> Agraharams were also known as '''Chaturvedimangalams''' in ancient times. They were also known as ghatoka, and boya.{{cn|date=October 2017}}
The name originates from the fact that the agraharams have lines of houses on either side of the road and the temple to the village god at the centre, thus resembling a garland around the temple. According to the traditional [[Hindu architecture|Hindu practice of architecture]] and town-planning, an agraharam is held to be two rows of houses running north-south on either side of a road at one end of which would be a temple to [[Shiva]] and at the other end, a temple to [[Vishnu]]. An example is [[Vadiveeswaram]] in Tamil Nadu.
With Brahmins taking up professions in urban areas and some migrating abroad agraharams are vanishing fast. Many of the traditional houses are giving way to concrete structures and commercial buildings.
== History ==
The earliest existing description of an ''agraharam'' has been found in a 3rd-century AD Sangam Age work called ''[[Perumpāṇāṟṟuppaṭai]]''.<ref name="srinivasaiyengar">{{cite book | title=History of the Tamils from the Earliest Times to 600 A. D.|author= P. T. Srinivasa Iyengar| authorlink= P. T. Srinivasa Iyengar | year=1929| publisher= | location=|pages=388–389}}</ref>
{{quotation|The houses had in front of them, a shed with short legs to which were tied fat calves; the houses were washed with cowdung and had idols (inside them). Domestic fowl and dogs did not approach them. It was the village of the guardians of the Veda who teach its sounds to the parrots with the bent mouth. If you (bard) reach (the place), fair faced bangled ladies who are as chaste as (Arundhathi) the little star which shines in the north of the bright, broad sky, will after sunset feed you on the well-cooked rice named after the bird (explained by the commentator as the rice called ''irasanam'') along with slices of citron boiled in butter taken, from the buttermilk derived from red cows and scented with the leaves of the karuvembu, and mixed with pepper-powder, and the sweet-smelling tender fruit plucked from the tall mango tree and pickled<ref name="srinivasaiyengar" />}}
== Places with the name ''Agraharam'' or ''Agrahara'' ==
=== Andhra Pradesh ===
There are a number of places in Andhra pradesh named ''agraharam''. These places may have originated as Bramhin-populated villages. Examples of such settlements include:
* Agraharam, Kanuru, in Peravali mandal of the [[West Godavari district]] of Andhra Pradesh state, India * Agraharam, Siddavaram, in Porumamilla mandal of [[Kadapa district]] of Andhra Pradesh state, India * Aatreyapuram Agraharam, village and a mandal in [[East Godavari district]] of Andhra Pradesh state, India. * Chennupalli Agraharam, in Ballikurva mandal of [[Prakasam district]] of Andhra Pradesh state India * Chintapalli agraharam, in Pentapadu mandal of [[West Godavari district]] of Andhra Pradesh state India
=== Karnataka ===
There are a number of places in Southern Karnataka named ''agrahara''. These places might have, probably, originated as Brahmin villages. * Agrahara,(near Baragur) Handikunte post, Sira taluk, Tumkur dist, Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Arkalgud]], in Hassan district of Karnataka state, India * [[Agrahara, Arsikere]], in Hassan district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Channarayapatna]], in Hassan district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Chiknayakanhalli]], in Tumkur district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Chintamani]], in Kolar district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Holalkere]], in Chitradurga district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Hosadurga]], in Chitradurga district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Hunsur]], in Mysore district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Kadur]], in Chikmagalur district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Kanakapura]], in Bangalore Rural district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Koratagere]], in Tumkur district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Malur]], in Kolar district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Sandur]], in Bellary district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Shrirangapattana]], in Mandya district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Sira]], in Tumkur district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara, Srinivaspur]], in Kolar district of Karnataka * [[Agrahara Bachahalli]], in Krishnarajpet taluk of Mandya district, Karnataka * [[Agrahara Palya]], in Bangalore North taluk of Bangalore district, Karnataka * [[Agrahara Somarasanahalli]], in Kola taluk of Kolar district, Karnataka * [[Agrahara Vaddahalli]], in Hosakote taluk of Bangalore Rural district, Karnataka * [[Agrahara Valagerehalli]], in Channapatna taluk of Bangalore Rural district, Karnataka * [[Konappana Agrahara]], town in [[Anekal taluk]] adjoining [[Electronics City]]. * [[Rupena Agrahara]] * Agrahara,(near Baragur) Handikunte post, Sira taluk, Tumkur dist, Karnataka
=== Tamil Nadu ===
* [[Annalagraharam]], village in [[Kumbakonam taluk]] of [[Thanjavur district]]. * [[Ganapathi Agraharam]], village in [[Thanjavur district]] * [[Pallipalayam Agraharam]], village in [[Namakkal district]]
=== Kerala === [[File:Kalpathy Agrahara, Palakkad, India4.jpg|thumbnail|Kalpathy Agrahara, Kerala]] *There is a famous Agraharam in [[Thiruvananthapuram]], Kerala called [[Valiyasala Mahadeva Temple|Valiya Sala]] which is the lengthiest Agraharam in India. *[[Agraharams]] in [[Palakkad]] district are around 96. When the villages are counted in the municipal area, there are around 18 of them. The concept is similar with houses in row on both sides and a temple at one end. They may differ in shapes - some are in straight line, some are T shaped and few have multiple temples within the village.
== Notes == {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.kuzhalmannamagraharam.info/ Kuzhalmannam Agraharam, one among agraharams of [[Palakkad]] where [[Kerala]] [[Iyers]] live.]

{{redirect|Bubi language|the other Gabonese language called Bubi|Vove language|the Bubi dialect of Kele|Kele language (Gabon)}} {{Infobox language |name=Bube |states= [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Gabon]], [[Cameroon]] |ethnicity=[[Bubi people|Bubi]], [[Wovea people|Wovea]] |speakers=51,000 |date=2011 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone A|Zone A.30]]) |fam6=perhaps [[Mbam languages|Mbam]]? |iso3=bvb |lc1=bbx |ld1=Bubia (Wovea) |guthrie=A.31, A.221 |glotto=bube1242 |glottorefname=Bube }} '''Bube''', '''Bohobé''' or '''Bube–Benga''' (Bobe, Bubi), is a [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] or [[Bantoid language]] spoken by the [[Bubi people|Bubi]], a [[Bantu people]] native to, and once the primary inhabitants of, [[Bioko Island]] in [[Equatorial Guinea]]. The language was brought to Bioko from continental Africa more than three thousand years ago when the [[Bubi people|Bubi]] began arriving on the island.[https://web.archive.org/web/19990903061913/http://www.equatorialguinea.org/event1390/event_show.htm?doc_id=2715 EquatorialGuinea.org; Retrieved 12/08/1998] It has around 50,000 speakers, with three variants: North, South and Central-East. It is noted for its [[Tone (linguistics)|tonal]] character and the divergence of words by gender. The language is also spoken by Bubi native to [[Gabon]] and [[Cameroon]]. The Bube language is divided into six different dialects that vary in the northern and southern regions of Bioko Island. For example, in the North, people speak ''Rebola'' and its variations: ''Basile'', ''Banapa'' and ''Basupa''. However, in the North-East, ''Bakake'' is spoken. Bube is also spoken in a small area on the mainland closest to the island, where speakers are shifting to [[Wumboko language|Wumboko]].Harald Hammarström (2013) ''Review of the Ethnologue, 16th Ed.'' This has been reported as "Bube", "Bubia" or "Wovea" (see [[Wovea people]]). The first Bube-to-English [[Primer (textbook)|primer]] was authored in 1875 by [[William Barleycorn]], a colonial era [[Primitive Methodist]] [[missionary]] of [[Igbo people|Igbo]] and [[Fernandino peoples|Fernandino]] descent, while he was serving in the Bubi village of [[Basupu]]. An official language dictionary and grammar guide was published by the ethnic Bubi scholar [[Justo Bolekia Boleká]]. == Other names== Other names and forms of the name include Bubé, eVoové, eBubée, Bhubhi, Bubi, Ibubi, Ibhubhi, Pove and Eviia. == Phonology == === Vowels === Bube has 7 vowels that can be either short or long: {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+Vowel phonemes |- ! ![[Front vowel|Front]] (short/[[Vowel length|long]])!! [[Back vowel|Back]] (short/[[Vowel length|long]]) |- ![[Close vowel|Close]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|i iː}} (ĩ) | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|u uː}} (ũ) |- ![[Close-mid vowel|Close-mid]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|e eː}} (ẽ) | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|o oː}} (õ) |- ![[Open-mid vowel|Open-mid]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|ɛ ɛː}} (ɛ̃) | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|ɔ ɔː}} (ɔ̃) |- ![[Open vowel|Open]] |colspan="2" style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|a aː}} (ã) |} The [[Nasalization|nasal]] vowels are [[allophone]]s of respective oral vowels. === Consonants === Bube has 20 consonants. Some of them are [[Prenasalized consonant|prenasalized]]: {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+Consonant Phonomes ! ![[Labial consonant|Labial]] ![[Dental consonant|Dental]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |-align=center ![[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|m}} | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|n}} | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|ɲ}} | style="font-size:larger;" | | |-align=center ![[Stop consonant|Stop]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|p b}} {{IPA|mp mb}} | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|t d}} {{IPA|nt nd}} | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|c ɟ}} {{IPA|ɲc ɲɟ}} | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|k ɡ}} | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|ʔ}} |-align=center ![[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|f v}} | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|s}} {{IPA|ns}} | | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|h}} |-align=center ! align="left" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|l}} | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|j}} | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|w}} | |-align=center ![[Pharyngeal consonant|Pharyngeal]] | | style="font-size:larger;" |{{IPA|ɾ}} | | | | |} == Numbers== :{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! {{Infobox language | name = Buryat | altname = Buriat | nativename = буряад хэлэн ''buryaad xelen'' | states = [[Russia]] ([[Buryat Republic]], [[Ust-Orda Buryat Autonomous Okrug|Ust-Orda Buryatia]], [[Agin-Buryat Autonomous Okrug|Aga Buryatia]]), northern [[Mongolia]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] ([[Hulunbuir]]) | ethnicity = [[Buryats]], [[Barga Mongols]] | speakers = 265,000 in Russia and Mongolia (2010 census); 65,000 in China | date = 1982 census | ref = e19 | refname = Buriat | familycolor = Altaic | fam1 = [[Mongolic languages|Mongolic]] | fam2 = Central Mongolic | nation = {{flag|Russia}}
  • {{flag|Buryatia}}
| script = [[Cyrillic]], [[Mongolian script]], [[Vagindra script]], [[Latin script|Latin]] | iso2 = bua | iso2comment = Buriat | iso3 = bua | iso3comment = Buriat | lc1 = bxu | ld1 = China Buriat | lc2 = bxm | ld2 = Mongolia Buriat | lc3 = bxr | ld3 = Russia Buriat | glotto = buri1258 | glottoname = Buriat | lingua = part of 44-BAA-b | notice = IPA }} '''Buryat''' or '''Buriat''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ʊr|i|æ|t}};Laurie Bauer, 2007, ''The Linguistics Student’s Handbook'', Edinburgh [[Cyrillic-derived alphabets#Buryat|Buryat Cyrillic]]: буряад хэлэн, ''buryaad xelen'') is a variety of the [[Mongolic languages]] spoken by the [[Buryats]] that is classified either as a language or major [[dialect]] group of [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]]. == Geographic distribution == [[File:Idioma_buriato.png|thumb|300px|Buryat language - Geographic distribution]] The majority of Buryat speakers live in [[Russia]] along the northern border of [[Mongolia]] where it is an official language in the [[Buryat Republic]], [[Ust-Orda Buryat Autonomous Okrug|Ust-Orda Buryatia]] and [[Agin-Buryat Autonomous Okrug|Aga Buryatia]].Skribnik 2003: 102, 105 In the Russian census of 2002, 353,113 people out of an ethnic population of 445,175 reported speaking Buryat (72.3%). Some other 15,694 can also speak Buryat, mostly ethnic Russians.[[Russian Census (2002)]] There are at least 100,000 ethnic Buryats in [[Mongolia]] and the [[People's Republic of China]] as well.Skribnik 2003: 102 Buryats in Russia have a separate [[literary language|literary standard]], written in a [[Cyrillic alphabets#Buryat|Cyrillic alphabet]].Skribnik 2003: 105 It is based on the Russian alphabet with three additional letters: [[Ue (Cyrillic)|Ү/ү]], [[Oe (Cyrillic)|Ө/ө]] and [[Һ|Һ/һ]]. ==Dialects== The delimitation of Buryat mostly concerns its relationship to its immediate neighbors, Mongolian proper and Khamnigan. While Khamnigan is sometimes regarded as a dialect of Buryat, this is not supported by [[isoglosses]]. The same holds for Tsongol and Sartul dialects, which rather group with [[Khalkha Mongolian]] to which they historically belong. Buryat dialects are: * Khori group east of Lake Baikal comprising Khori, Aga, Tugnui, and North Selenga dialects. Khori is also spoken by most Buryats in Mongolia and a few speakers in [[Hulunbuir]]. * Lower Uda (Nizhneudinsk) dialect, the dialect situated furthest to the west and which shows the strongest influence by [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] * Alar–Tunka group comprising Alar, Tunka–Oka, Zakamna, and Unga in the southwest of [[Lake Baikal]] in the case of Tunka also in Mongolia. * Ekhirit–Bulagat group in the Ust’-Orda National District comprising Ekhirit–Bulagat, Bokhan, Ol’khon, Barguzin, and Baikal–Kudara * Bargut group in Hulunbuir (which is historically known as Barga), comprising Old Bargut and New BargutSkribnik 2003: 104 Based on loan vocabulary, a division might be drawn between Russia Buriat, Mongolia Buriat and China Buriat.Gordon (ed.) 2005 However, as the influence of Russian is much stronger in the dialects traditionally spoken west of Lake Baikal, a division might rather be drawn between the Khori and Bargut group on the one hand and the other three groups on the other hand.Skribnik 2003: 102, 104 ==Phonology== Buryat has the [[vowel]] [[phoneme]]s /i, ɯ, e, a, u, ʊ, o, ɔ/ (plus a few diphthongs),Poppe 1960: 8 short /e/ being realized as [ɯ], and the [[consonant]] phonemes /b, g, d, tʰ, m, n, x, l, r/ (each with a corresponding [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]] phoneme) and /s, ʃ, z, ʒ, h, j/.Svantesson, Tsendina and Karlsson 2008, p. 146.Svantesson et al. 2005: 146; the status of [ŋ] is problematic, see Skribnik 2003: 107. In Poppe 1960's description, places of vowel articulation are somewhat more fronted. These vowels are restricted in their occurrence according to [[vowel harmony]].Skribnik 2003: 107 The basic syllable structure is (C)V(C) in careful articulation, but word-final CC clusters may occur in more rapid speech if short vowels of non-initial syllables get dropped.Poppe 1960: 13-14 === Vowels === {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |- ! !! [[Front vowel|Front]] !! [[Central vowel|Central]] ! colspan="2" |[[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Close vowel|Close]] | rowspan="2" |i|| rowspan="2" | |ɯ |u |- | colspan="2" |ʊ |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | rowspan="2" |e|| rowspan="2" |(ə) | colspan="2" |o |- | colspan="2" |ɔ |- ![[Open vowel|Open]] | |a | colspan="2" | |} [ɯ] only occurs as a sound of a short ''e''. [ə] is only an allophone of unstressed vowels. === Consonants === {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" |[[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! colspan="2" |[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2" |[[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- !plain ![[Palatalization (phonetics)|pal.]] !plain ![[Palatalization (phonetics)|pal.]] !plain ![[Palatalization (phonetics)|pal.]] |- align="center" ! rowspan="2" |[[Stop consonant|Plosive]] !voiceless | | |tʰ |tʲʰ | | | | |- align="center" !voiced |b |bʲ |d |dʲ | |ɡ |ɡʲ | |- align="center" ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !voiceless | | |s | |ʃ |x |xʲ |h |- align="center" !voiced | | |z | |ʒ | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m |mʲ |n |nʲ | |(ŋ) | | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | |l |lʲ | | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | |r |rʲ | | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | | |j | | | |} [ŋ] only occurs as an allophone of /n/. ===Stress=== Lexical [[Stress (linguistics)|stress]] (word accent) falls on the last [[Syllable weight|heavy]] nonfinal [[syllable]] when one exists. Otherwise, it falls on the word-final heavy syllable when one exists. If there are no heavy syllables, then the initial syllable is stressed. Heavy syllables without primary stress receive [[secondary stress]]:Walker 1997 :{| | ˌHˈ'''H'''L || {{IPA|[ˌøːɡˈʃøːxe]}} || "to act encouragingly" |- | LˌHˈ'''H'''L || {{IPA|[naˌmaːˈtuːlxa]}} || "to cause to be covered with leaves" |- | ˌHLˌHˈ'''H'''L || {{IPA|[ˌbuːzaˌnuːˈdiːje]}} || "steamed dumplings (accusative)" |- | ˌHˈ'''H'''LLL || {{IPA|[ˌtaːˈruːlaɡdaxa]}} || "to be adapted to" |- | ˈ'''H'''ˌH || {{IPA|[ˈboːˌsoː]}} || "bet" |- | Lˈ'''H'''ˌH || {{IPA|[daˈlaiˌɡaːr]}} || "by sea" |- | Lˈ'''H'''LˌH || {{IPA|[xuˈdaːliŋɡˌdaː]}} || "to the husband's parents" |- | LˌHˈ'''H'''ˌH || {{IPA|[daˌlaiˈɡaːˌraː]}} || "by one's own sea" |- | ˌHLˈ'''H'''ˌH || {{IPA|[ˌxyːxenˈɡeːˌreː]}} || "by one's own girl" |- | L'''ˈH''' || {{IPA|[xaˈdaːr]}} || "through the mountain" |- | ˈ'''L'''L || {{IPA|[ˈxada]}} || "mountain"Walker 1997: 27-28 |} Secondary stress may also occur on word-initial [[Syllable weight|light]] syllables without primary stress, but further research is required. {{Infobox music festival | name =Castlemorton Common Festival | image = [[Image:Castlemorton_Festival.jpg|200px|Sky view of the Castlemorton Festival site.]] | caption = | location =[[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]], [[Worcestershire]], [[England]] | years_active =1992 | founders = | dates = 22-29 May 1992 | genre = [[Breakbeat Hardcore]], [[Techno]], [[House music|House]], [[Anarcho Punk]] | attendance =20,000-40,000 | capacity = | website = }}
The '''Castlemorton Common Festival''' was a week-long [[free party|free festival]] and [[rave]] held in the [[Malvern Hills (district)|Malvern Hills]] near [[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]], [[Worcestershire]], [[England]] between 22nd–29th May 1992.<ref name="lynskey">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/jun/15/castlemorton-triggers-rave-crackdown| title=Castlemorton triggers the rave crackdown| author= Lynskey, Dorian | work=The Guardian| date= 15 June 2011| accessdate= 26 May 2016 }}</ref> The media interest and controversy surrounding the festival, and concerns as to the way it was policed, inspired the legislation that would eventually became the [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]].<ref name="fielding page 113"/><ref name="BBC">{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-39960232|title= Castlemorton Common: The rave that changed the law |last= Chester| first= Jerry |date= 28 May 2017|publisher= BBC News | accessdate= 28 May 2017 }}</ref>
==History==
===Background=== In May 1992 [[Avon and Somerset Constabulary|Avon and Somerset Police]] tried to end the annual Avon Free Festival, which had been held in the [[Bristol]] area around the May [[Bank Holiday]] for several years.<ref name="mckay page 120">McKay, G. (1996) ''Senseless Acts of Beauty: Cultures of Resistance'', Page 120, Verso {{ISBN|1-85984-908-3}}</ref> As a result, hundreds of [[new age travellers]] en-route to the area for the expected festival were shunted into neighbouring counties by Avon and Somerset’s Operation Nomad police manoeuvres, with [[West Mercia Police]] deciding to confine them to common land at [[Castlemorton]].<ref name="lynskey"></ref>
===The rave=== The high-profile coverage in the national media only served to swell the crowd further as ravers from far afield made their way to join the festival, thus making it an impossible task for the authorities to close the event down.<ref name="BBC"></ref> An estimated 20,000-40,000 people gathered on Castlemorton Common for the party which lasted a full week, the biggest of its kind since the [[Stonehenge Free Festival]] in the mid-1980s.<ref name="page 131 During">During, S. (2005) ''Cultural Studies: A Critical Introduction'', Page 131, Routledge {{ISBN|0-415-24656-3}}</ref>
Castlemorton hosted many of the large [[Sound system (DJ)|sound systems]] of the time such as [[Bedlam sound system|Bedlam]], Circus Warp, [[Spiral Tribe]] and [[DiY Sound System]], and bands such as [[Back To The Planet]], Xenophobia (fronted by Spiral Tribe's MC Skallywag), [[AOS3]] and [[Poisoned Electrick Head]].<ref name="djmag">{{cite web|url=https://djmag.com/content/free-party-politics-castle-morton | title=Free Party Politics: Castle Morton|author=Whitehurst, Andrew|work=DJ Mag | date= 28 March 2014 | accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> <ref name="Carney page 141">Carney, B. (2010) ''Take Your Protein Pills...'', Page 141, Lulu {{ISBN|978-1-4452-6411-0}}</ref>
Simon Reynolds wrote that "during the next five days of its existence, Castlemorton will inspire questions in Parliament, make the front page of every newspaper in England and incite nationwide panic about the whereabouts of the next destination on the crusty itinerary." <ref name="reynolds">Reynolds, S. (1998) ''Energy Flash'', Pages 135-140, Picador {{ISBN|0-5712-8914-2}}</ref>
The then local [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|MP]] [[Michael Spicer]], speaking in a [[House of Commons]] debate remarked: "The invasion that took place at Castlemorton common in my constituency, on Friday 22 May, has prompted me to do so again. On that day, new age travellers, ravers and drugs racketeers arrived at a strength of two motorised army divisions, complete with several massed bands and, above all, a highly sophisticated command and signals system. However, they failed to bring latrines. The numbers, speed and efficiency with which they arrived--amounting at one time to as many as 30,000 people--combined to terrorise the local community to the extent that some residents had to undergo psychiatric treatment in the days that followed. Such an incident must never happen again, in my constituency or elsewhere. We need tighter laws, especially to give banning powers to the police ; a Cabinet Committee to bring responsible Departments together ; quicker and more co-ordinated police action ; and a more effective application of existing policies by national and local authorities".<ref name="hansard">{{cite hansard | house=House of Commons |date = 29 June 1992 |volume=6, 210|column = 688}}</ref> ===Aftermath=== Thirteen members of [[Spiral Tribe]] were arrested after the event, and charged with public order offences. After a lengthy and costly trial, they were acquitted.<ref name="lynskey"></ref>
Concerns about the festival and the way in which it was policed inspired the legislation which developed into the [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]].<ref name="fielding page 113">Fielding, N. (2005) ''The Police and Social Conflict'', Page 113, Routledge Cavendish {{ISBN|1-904385-23-0}}</ref> This wide-ranging Act effectively made illegal such outdoor parties that played music, which was defined in section 63(1)(b) to include "sounds wholly or predominantly characterised by the emission of a succession of repetitive beats."
Whilst some have argued that Castlemorton, with its attendant publicity, led directly to the Criminal Justice Act and was the "final nail in the coffin of the unlicensed event",<ref>ed. South N. (1999) ''Drugs: Cultures, Controls and Everyday Life'', Page 30, SAGE Publications {{ISBN|0-7619-5235-7}}</ref> others have seen the Act as a draconian piece of legislation which was "explicitly aimed at suppressing the activities of certain strands of alternative culture".<ref>Gilbert J. (1999) ''Discographies: Dance Music, Culture, and the Politics of Sound'', Page 150, Routledge {{ISBN|0-415-17032-X}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]] * [[List of electronic music festivals]] * [[List of free parties]] * [[Spiral Tribe]] * [[Teknival]] * [[DiY Sound System]]

[[File:Historical map of the Casuari in the time of Ptolemy.png|thumb|This is a map of where roughly the ancient Germanic tribe the Casuari lived as described by Ptolemy.]] The '''Casuari''' were an ancient Germanic people. [[Ptolemy]] mentions them as living on the southern border of Germany, east of the Abnoba mountains, that are east of the Rhine. They were therefore neighbours of the [[Tencteri]], a tribe living between the Rhine and the Abnoba mountains. Their origins can be traced back to those of the [[Alemanni]] and Khatti, they descend from Assyrian tribes who migrated into Europe to settle. Ptolemy also mentions them as having founded the town of Suevos Casuari. The Casuari were most likely numerous during and around the time of Ptolemy, which is around 90 to 168 AD. Being a small tribe, very little remains of them, and most evidence comes from written sources.<ref>https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OlA1BGEV3QwC&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=casuari+germanic+tribe&source=bl&ots=Lf5m-PNam3&sig=83f7yBM9V9UMMpvysmafMXmB8_c&hl=en&sa=X&ei=32C5VPKOLcvV7QbnrIHIBg&sqi=2&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=casuari%20germanic%20tribe&f=false</ref><ref>http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Periods/Roman/_Texts/Ptolemy/2/10/limited.html</ref>
==Language==
The Casuari spoke a [[South Germanic]] dialect, related to the High, or Upper Germanic languages. The location of their tribe was in fact a crossroad between the [[Weser-Rhine Germanic]] and [[Elbe Germanic]] languages. If so, their language originated from the Rhine, Alps, Elba or the North Sea from Friesland to Jutland.
==Fall of the Western Roman Empire==
By the time of the fall of the [[Western Roman Empire]], the Casuari had most probably been conquered by the Romans, or had either become part of the Alemanni or another major Germanic tribe on the Rhine river.<ref>http://www.sparknotes.com/history/european/rome4/section3.rhtml</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{about|the process and history of counting Malaysia's population|information on current and historical census and other data|Demographics of Malaysia}} {{refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{see also|2010 Malaysian Census}} {{Infobox census | name = Population and Housing Census of Malaysia, 2010 | logo = | logo_caption = [[Department of Statistics (Malaysia)|Department of Statistics]] | image = | image_caption = | country = Malaysia | date = 6 July–22 August 2010 | population = 28,334,135 | percent_change = {{increase}} 2.0% | region_type = state / federal territory | most_populous = {{nowrap|[[Selangor]] (5,462,141)}} | least_populous = {{nowrap|[[Putrajaya]] (72,413)}} }} The '''census in Malaysia''', or officially, the '''Population and Housing Census''', is a descriptive count of everyone who is in [[Malaysia]] on the [[Census Day]], and of their [[dwellings]]. The decennial Malaysian census has been conducted six times, As of 2010. It has been conducted every 10 years, beginning in 1960. ==Overview== The decennial publication provides users with the final Malaysian Census population figures for basic demographic characteristics such as gender, age distribution, ethnic group, citizenship, religion and marital status at the state and the administrative district levels. Some of the tables also provide a breakdown by urban and rural areas. Malaysia consists of thirteen [[States and federal territories of Malaysia|states and three federal territories]]. Each state is divided into several [[Districts of Malaysia|administrative districts]]. In Kelantan, the administrative district is known as "Jajahan". Each state is also stratified into urban and rural areas. Urban and rural areas are not legally defined administrative areas but are statistically defined to distinguish areas with certain socio-economic characteristics. ==Data source== The data in the decennial publication represent final Malaysian Census population figures for respective decades. As in censuses in most other countries, the information obtained during enumeration is subject to coverage and content errors. In term of coverage errors, part of living quarters, households or population maybe left out, erronerously included or duplicated. Content errors in particular were based on erronerous responses on gender, age, ethnic group, citizenship, religion and marital status. As a result, the figures were "adjusted" based on the estimates of under-enumeration derived from the Census Coverage Evaluation Survey. ==Census approach== As of Census 2010, a multi-modal data collection data method was used as follows: * Face to face interview ** The enumerator will visit every living quarters to interview and obtain the individual's information. * Self enumeration ** Drop-off and pick-up (DOPU) *** The enumerator will drop-off the Census Kit containing a [[questionnaire]] and related documents. The questionnaire should be completed by the respondent and the enumerator will pick-up the duly completed questionnaire upon on agreed date and time. ** e-Census *** The respondent will complete the questionnaire online via the website www.statistic.com.my. The identification particulars are provided in the Census Kit to enable respondent to access e-Census. Two types of census questionnaires were used. The first questionnaire for persons living in private living quarters, whilst the second questionnaire was for persons living in collective living quarters such as college or university hostels, charitable or social welfare institutions, prisons and homeless persons. ==Census coverage== {{see also|:Category:Malaysian expatriates|:Category:Expatriates in Malaysia}} ===Inclusion of person=== As of Census 2010, it covered all persons including non-citizens who had stayed or intended to stay in Malaysia for more than six months in the year 2010. This includes: * Persons commuting across the Malaysian border (e.g. Singapore, Thailand, Brunei, Indonesia) for work or study but maintaining usual residence within Malaysia; * Malaysians who were overseas as tourists, on short term study or attending conference, seminar or on business; * Expatriates and other foreign workers as well as their family members; * Foreign visitors and students; * Foreign military, naval and diplomatic personnel and their families staying in the country except for those who have [[diplomatic immunity]] and wished to be excluded; * Person living in the college or university hostels; * Person living in the charitable or social welfare institutions; * Prisoners; and * Persons without permanent homes or [[homelessness]]. ===Exclusion of person=== The following categories were excluded from the census count on the basis that they were staying in the country for less than six months in the year 2010: * Malaysian citizens and permanent residents who were away or intended to be away from the country for more than six months in the year 2010 because of work, studies, etc.; * Military, naval and diplomatic personnel and their families who were staying outside Malaysia; and * Foreigners such as tourists, businessmen and the like who were in Malaysia for less than six months. ===Topics covered in the censuses=== {| border=1 style="border-collapse:collapse; text-align:left; font-size:100%; border:2px solid blue;" |+ '''Topics Covered in the Population and Housing Censuses of Four Pan-Malaysia Censuses, 1970–2000''' |- style="text-align:center; color:white; font-weight:bold; background:red;" ! colspan=5| Economic Characteristics |- | Type of economic activity (during previous weeks) || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} |- | Number of hours worked (during previous weeks) || {{na}} || {{na}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} |- | Type of economic activity (during previous weeks) || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{na}} || {{na}} |- | Occupation || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} |- | Industry || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} |- | Employment status || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} || {{ya}} |- | Occupation sector (government / private / individual) || {{na}} || {{na}} || {{na}} || {{ya}} |} ==Concepts and definitions== ===Urban areas=== Urban areas adopted by the previous censuses refer to gazetted local council areas with a specified population threshold. The urban areas in Census 1980 refers to a gazetted area with population of 10,000 persons or more. Urban areas in Census 1991 and 2000, were defined as gazetted areas with their adjoining built-up areas which had a combined population of 10,000 or more. Built-up areas were defined as areas contiguous to a gazetted area and had at least 60 per cent of their population (aged 10 and above) engaged in non-agricultural activities as well as having modern toilet facilities in their housing units. The definition of urban areas for Census 2000 also takes into account the special development area namely development area which is not gazetted and can be identified and separated from the gazetted area or built-up area of more than 5 km and a population of at least 10,000 with 60 per cent of their population (aged 10 and above) engaged in non-agricultural activities as well as having modern toilet facilities in their housing units. Meanwhile, urban areas in Census 2010, were defined as: {{quote|Gazetted areas with their adjoining built-up areas which had a combined population of 10,000 or more. Built-up areas were defined as areas contiguous to a gazetted areas and had at least 60 per cent of their population (aged 15 years and above) engaged in non-agricultural activities. The definition of urban areas also takes into account the special development area namely development area which is not gazetted and can be identified and separated from the gazetted area or built-up area of more than 5 km and a population of at least 10,000 with 60 per cent of their population (aged 15 and above) engaged in non-agricultural activities as well as having modern toilet facilities in their housing units.}} Urbanisation is a dynamic process and keeps changing with development and growth. Thus, the urban areas for 1980, 1991, 2000 and 2010 Censuses do not necessarily refer to the same areas, as areas fulfilling the above criteria of urban continue to expand and grow. ===Ethnic groups and citizenship=== Classification of 2010 Census ethnic group is as set by Inter-Agency Technical Committee (IATC) in Appendix 1. IATC is a committee formed to co-ordinate and monitor the implementation and use of standardised codes, classifications and definitions used by the Department of Statistics, Malaysia and other government agencies.  |} {| class=wikitable | : r = the average annual population growth rate : n = the exact number of years between PO and Pn : PO = the population at the initial year : Pn = the population at the later year : In = the natural logarithm |} ===Population density=== The density of persons per square kilometre is the ratio of the population of a given geographic area to the number of square kilometres in the same area. ===Median age=== The median age is the age that divides the distribution of the population into two, such that half the population is below the age and half is above it. ===Dependency ratio=== Dependency ratio refers to the ratio of the number of persons below the age of 15 years and the number of persons aged 65 years and over to the number of persons aged 15–64 years; multiplied by 100. ===Sex ratio=== The sex ratio is the number of males per 100 females. ===Marital status=== * Never married ** Refers to persons who were never married * Married ** Refers to persons who were currently married at the time of enumeration. The term 'married', includes those married by law or by religious rites or were living together by mutual agreement. * Widowed ** Refers to those whose marriages were terminated through death of their spouses and were not remarried at the time of enumeration. * Divorced / permanently separated ** Refers to those whose marriages were terminated through divorce by law or religion agreement or separated for a long duration without any possibility of reconcillation. ===Mean age at first marriage=== The mean age at first marriage refers to the singulate mean age at marriage which is an indicate measure of the mean age at first marriage among those who would ever marry. It is derived from the proportions never married at different age groups. ===Religion=== Refers to the identification or relationship of an individual to a system of beliefs and the practice of these beliefs. For the purpose of tabulation and analysis, the classification for religion is as follows: * [[Islam in Malaysia|Islam]]; * [[Christianity in Malaysia|Christianity]]; * [[Buddhism in Malaysia|Buddhism]]; * [[Hinduism]]; * [[Religion in Malaysia#Other|Confucianism, Taoism and Tribal / Folk / Other traditional Chinese religion]]; * Other religion including [[Sikhism]] and Bahai; * No religion; and * Unknown. ===Area or boundary changes=== After the year 2000, there were several new areas created or boundary changes that were gazetted by the relevant authority for federal territory and administrative districts. The new federal territory created was Putrajaya. Meanwhile, the new administrative districts such as Ledang and Kulaijaya in Johor; Pokok Sena in Kedah; Kampar in Perak; Putatan in Sabah; and Pakan and Selangau in Sarawak. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150301154300/http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf Population and Housing Census of Malaysia, 2010] ==Further reading== * {{citation|author=Saw Swee-Hock|title=The Population of Malaysia (Second Edition)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=33FpBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA9 |date=6 January 2015|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=978-981-4620-36-9|pages=|authormask=|format=|origyear=|oclc=|doi=|bibcode=|id=|quote=|laysummary=|laydate=}} {{Asia topic|Census in}} [[Category:Censuses in Malaysia]] [[Category:Government of Malaysia]] [[Category:National censuses]]

{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Daingnet | native_name = {{nobold|ဒိုင်းနက်}} | native_name_lang = my | image = Daignet Men.JPG | image_caption = | total = 80,000 | total_year = | total_source = estimate | total_ref = | regions = {{flag|Myanmar}} ([[Rakhine State]]) | languages = [[Chakma language|Chakma]]{{·}}[[Burmese language|Burmese]] | religions = [[Theravada Buddhism]] | related_groups = [[Chakma people|Chakmas]], [[Burman people|Burmans]], [[Rakhine people|Rakhines]], [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]] | footnotes = }}
The '''Daingnet people''' ({{lang-my|ဒိုင်းနက်လူမျိုး}}), also known as the '''Thetkama people''' ({{lang-my|သက္ကမ}})<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://burmese.dvb.no/archives/247045|title=သက္ကမ (ဒိုင်းနက်) တိုင်ရင်းသားများ အမျိုးသားနေ့ ကျင်းပ |website=burmese.dvb.no|language=my|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref> are an [[Ethnicity|ethnic group]] indigenous to northern [[Rakhine State]], [[Myanmar]]. According to their own internal census in 1995 they numbered about 60,000. In 2011, the number is estimated to be around 80,000. From appearance they are indistinguishable from the [[Rakhine people]]; however, the Daingnet people have a distinct language and culture. Ethnically, they are closely related to the [[Chakma people]] of Bangladesh and Northeast India. The languages of the Daingnet and Chakma people are mutually intelligible. Daingnet people are one of 135 ethnic groups officially recognized by the [[Myanmar government]] as indigenous to [[Myanmar]]. Daingnets are one of the Tibeto-Burman tribes. Genetically they are closely related to the [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]], [[Burman people|Burmans]] and [[Rakhine people|Rakhines]].
== Etymology == Daingnets do not call themselves ''Daingnet''; instead they call themselves ''Thaikhma'' like the nearby [[Chakma people]] of [[Bangladesh]] and [[Northeast India]]. They are believed to have originated from greater Arakan Yoma North, presently [[Chin State]] (previously Sak Buddhist homeland "Chacomas", occupied by Zo people from [[Lushai Hills]]). Daingnet is an [[Exonym and endonym|exonym]] originally used by [[Rakhine people]]. In [[Arakanese language|Rakhine language]], Daingnet means "shield warriors" or "armored warriors". Centuries ago the Rakhine kings hired the Daingnets as soldiers and they showed their mastery with shield and sword. The Daingnets no longer fight with shield and sword, but the name Daingnet stuck''.''
== History == Daingnets are indigenous to Rakhine State. They were among the first people who settled in northern Rakhine State. During [[British rule in Burma]], the Daingnets were classified as Sak people. ''Sak'' is a generic term used by the [[Bamar people|Bamar]] and Rakhine peoples to denote the [[Chakma people]].
In the spring of 1798, British explorer Francis Buchanan visited [[Chittagong Hill Tracts]], he asked a Chakma man if they were the same as ''Sak'' people in Rakhine State. The man replied, the ''Saks'' of Rakhine State were ''Moishang Saks''.<ref name=Buchanan>{{cite book|last=Buchanan|first=Francis|title=Francis Buchanan in Southeast Bengal|year=1992|publisher=Dhaka University Press|location=|isbn=984-05-1192-0|pages=108}}</ref> In the Rakhine language ''Moishang'' means primary or superior. What the man meant was, the Saks of Rakhine State retained the original Chakma language. Though Francis Buchanan did not visit Rakhine State he was aware of the ''Sak'' people from his earlier visit to [[Cox's Bazar]]. He might have heard about them from the [[East India Company]] officials or the Rakhine refugees who were pouring into [[Cox's Bazar]] to flee Burma-Rakhine conflict.
According to Burmese historian [[Gordon Luce]], the ''Saks'' (i.e. ancestors of the Daingnets) attained higher cultural level than any other minority peoples in Arakan. They were the smelters of iron, the distillers of spirits, the makers of earthen vessels, manufacturers of salt, builders of boats etc.<ref name=Gutman>{{cite book|last=Gutman|first=Pamela|title=Ancient Arakan|year=1976|publisher=Australian National University Press|location=|isbn=|pages=13}} </ref>
== Distribution == The Daingnet people are found in and around [[Maungdaw]], [[Buthidaung]], [[Kyauktaw]], [[Paletwa Township|Paletwa]] and [[Mrauk-U]]. Many Daingnets also live in the [[Arakan Yoma]] mountains, close to the [[Chin state]] and [[Chittagong Hill Tracts]].
== Culture == The Daingnets are culturally similar to the [[Chakma people|Chakmas]] and [[Rakhine people|Rakhines]] in [[Bangladesh]] and [[Northeast India]]. Rice, fish and vegetables are their favorite foods. They prefer hot food. Daingnet people consider cow as a sacred animal and as such they do not eat beef. Men sport ''lungi'' and women sport sarong ([[Pinuin]]) like dress ''thami''. Usually men do the agricultural work and women look after children and cook for the family. They usually like to settle near rivers. Some of them also live in mountains whose livelihood is [[slash and burn]] cultivation. Daingnet people usually marry early, but never before the age of 17.
Their original language was [[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]]. Due to prolonged interaction with the [[Assamese language]], their language gradually became a mix of [[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]] and [[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]]. Majority of the Daingnets are multi-lingual. Apart from their own [[Chakma language]], they can speak [[Rakhine language|Rakhine]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]] and in [[Chittagonian language|Chittagonian]] (a dialect of [[Bengali language|Bengali]]).
== Religion == Daingnets are followers of [[Theravada Buddhism]] and for centuries the Daingnets have strictly adhered to its teachings.<ref name=Hattaway>{{cite book|last=Hattaway|first=Paul|title=Peoples of the Buddhist World|year=2004|publisher=Authentic Media|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1-903689-90-2|pages=42}}</ref> Almost every village has a Buddhist temple. A Daingnet male at least once in his lifetime becomes a Buddhist monk. However most of them do not remain Buddhist monks for life. Wedding and funeral ceremonies are performed by Buddhist monks. Besides wedding and funeral, the Daingnet people flock to Buddhist temples on major Buddhist festivals which usually fall on full moon days.
== Economy == Majority of the Daingnets are farmers. Some of them are traders. Their economy is highly dependent on agriculture and hence vulnerable to weather pattern. However, due to lack of economic development there is widespread poverty among the Daingnets.<ref name=Diran>{{cite book|last=Diran|first=Richard K.|title=Vanishing Tribes of Burma|year=1997|publisher=Amphoto Books-Random House|location=|isbn=0-8174-5559-0|pages=}}</ref> Religious conviction of [[Buddhism]] forbids them to work as fishermen or butchers. There are 2 kinds of farmers among the Daingnets, those who farm land on permanent basis and those who farm hills and mountains by [[slash and burn]] or [[shifting cultivation]] technique.
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2017}} '''Corryn Veronica Ann Rayney''', née Da Silva, (born 1963) migrated to Australia with her Indian family in 1973 as refugees from [[Idi Amin]]'s [[Uganda]].<ref name=victim>{{cite web|author=Christiana Jones |url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/full-coverage/rayney-trial/a/-/article/14225410|title=The victim: Corryn Rayney|date=13 July 2012|publisher=[[The West Australian]] |accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Anne-Louise Brown |url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/who-are-the-rayneys-20120713-2208e.html|title=Who are The Rayneys?|date=13 July 2012|publisher=WA Today (Fairfax Media)|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Christiana Jones|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/wa/14355904/pain-is-clear-as-proud-dad-tells-of-memories/ |title=Pain is clear as proud dad tells of memories|publisher=[[The West Australian]] |date=25 July 2012|accessdate=17 September 2012}}</ref> Her death occurred on or about 7 August 2007, her body being discovered a week later in a clandestine grave in [[Kings Park, Western Australia|Kings Park]], [[Perth]], with no clearly established cause of death.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anne-Louise Brown |url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/no-cause-of-death-revealed-in-rayney-case-20120808-23uem.html |title=No cause of death revealed in Rayney case |publisher=WA Today (Fairfax Media) |date=16 July 2012 |accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> Her husband [[Lloyd Rayney]], a prominent barrister specialising in criminal prosecution, was charged with her murder but found not guilty after a trial before a judge only.<ref name=ABCNewsNotGuilty>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-11-01/verdict-handed-down-in-rayney-trial/4346322|title=Lloyd Rayney found not guilty of murder|publisher=ABC News|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> The acquittal was unanimously upheld by a court of appeal in August 2013. The state's police commissioner and attorney general declined to acknowledge documented procedural mistakes, and refused to instigate a fresh search for the killers, leading to calls for a federal investigation into the matter.
The Rayneys had two daughters<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://news.smh.com.au/national/lawyer-appeals-for-info-on-missing-wife-20070813-t0x.html |title=Lawyer appeals for info on missing wife |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=13 August 2007 |accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> and lived in the Perth suburb of [[Como, Western Australia|Como]]. At the time, Lloyd Rayney was involved in a Corruption and Crime Commission inquiry into the misconduct of police officers in a murder investigation.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Corryn Rayney was employed as a registrar at the Supreme Court of Western Australia. She was last seen alive at 9.30 p.m. on 7 August 2007 at a [[Boot scooting|bootscooting]] class.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.smh.com.au/national/police-concerned-for-missing-mum-20070809-sho.html |title=Police concerned for missing mum |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=9 August 2007 |accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref> A week later, police discovered her abandoned car and followed a trail of oil from it to the grave in Kings Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.smh.com.au/national/police-scour-perth-for-missing-mum-20070815-tf7.html |title=Police scour Perth for missing mum |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref>
==Investigation and trial== Although Lloyd Rayney was controversially<ref>{{cite web|title=The Jack Lee incident|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/full-coverage/rayney-trial/a/-/article/14224959|date=13 July 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012|author=Christiana Jones|publisher=[[The West Australian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/i-didnt-leak-to-media-senior-sergeant-jack-lee-testifies-at-lloyd-rayney-murder-trial/story-fndo4e3y-1226464835988|date=5 September 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012|author=Wendy Cachetta|publisher=Perth Now (''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]]'')|title='Prime suspect' cop Sen Sgt Jack Lee takes Rayney witness stand}}</ref> described by the chief police investigator Senior Sergeant Jack Lee as the "only suspect" at a police press conference in September 2007,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/wa/14757025/investigation-biased-single-minded/|author=Christiana Jones|publisher=[[The West Australian]]|title=Investigation: biased, single-minded|date=5 September 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref> he was not charged with the murder until December 2010, more than three years after the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/rayney-freed-on-bail-to-spend-christmas-with-daughters-20101223-196d3.html |title=Rayney freed on bail to spend Christmas with daughters|publisher=WA Today (Fairfax Media) |date=23 December 2010 |accessdate=20 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Aja Styles |url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/lloyd-rayney-charged-with-wilful-murder-after-innercity-arrest-20101208-18pax.html |title=Lloyd Rayney charged with wilful murder after inner-city arrest|publisher=WA Today (Fairfax Media) |date=8 December 2010|accessdate=7 September 2012}}</ref>
An affidavit filed by the prosecutors indicated that the case was circumstantial.<ref name=Robertson>{{cite web|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/court-lifts-suppression-order-on-rayney-trial-application/story-e6frg13u-1226293857544|date=8 March 2012|accessdate=23 September 2013|author=Katie Robertson|publisher=Perth Now (''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]]'')|title=Court lifts suppression order on Rayney trial application}}</ref> The prosecutor's opening address to the trial said that the state's case was circumstantial but the evidence of motive was compelling.<ref name=Brown>{{cite web|author=Anne-Louise Brown|url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/rayney-trial-first-witness-called-20120723-22k7x.html|title=Rayney Trial: First witness called|publisher=WA Today (Fairfax Media) |date=23 July 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref>
At the request of the defendant in October 2011,<ref name=Robertson/> the trial was heard by a judge only, with no jury. The reasons for the application were suppressed at the time, but later published in March 2012.<ref name=Robertson/> Lloyd Rayney wanted a trial without a jury, because he claimed that the extensive publicity would make a fair jury trial impossible to achieve. The decision to conduct the trial without a jury was a subject of debate in Australian legal circles.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Fisher|url=http://theconversation.edu.au/twelve-good-men-and-women-lloyd-rayney-and-the-problem-with-jury-trials-8554|publisher=The Conversation|title=Twelve good men (and women)? Lloyd Rayney and the problem with jury trials|date=1 August 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Leanne Mezrani|url=http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/news/juryless-murder-trial-is-offensive|work=Lawyers Weekly|title=Juryless murder trial is offensive|date=12 July 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref>
Former Northern Territory Chief Justice [[Brian Ross Martin]] was appointed as an Acting Justice of the Western Australia Supreme Court in February 2012 to preside over the trial;<ref>{{cite web|title=Supreme Court judge appointed for Rayney trial|publisher=ABC News|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-12-29/supreme-court-judge-appointed-for-rayney-trial/3751406|date=29 December 2011|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref> a judge from outside Western Australia was used to ensure impartiality, given that both the victim and accused had held senior legal positions.<ref>{{cite web|author=Christiana Jones|publisher=[[The West Australian]]|title=The Judge: Brian Martin|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/full-coverage/rayney-trial/a/-/article/14225053|date=13 July 2012|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref>
The trial began on 16 July 2012,<ref name=full_judgment>[http://decisions.justice.wa.gov.au/supreme/supdcsn.nsf/PDFJudgments-WebVw/2012WASC0404/%24FILE/2012WASC0404.pdf The State of Western Australia v Rayney] Full Judgment, 369pp., 1 November 2012</ref> and ran until 19 October 2012 when final submissions were presented by prosecutor John Agius SC, QC<ref>[http://www.sljc.com/members.html Members of (Sir Lawrence Jackson) Chambers, Perth]. Retrieved 20 October 2012</ref> and defence counsel David Edwardson QC.<ref>[http://www.barchambers.com.au/?section=115&id=174 David Edwardson QC] at Bar Chambers, Adelaide</ref> On 1 November, Justice Martin acquitted Lloyd Rayney when he handed down a judgment of "not guilty", saying that the "case by the State is beset by improbabilities and uncertainties".<ref name=ABCNewsNotGuilty/> The full reasons for the verdict were published, a requirement which would not have applied to a jury verdict.<ref name=bail>{{cite news|author = Christiana Jones|title = Judge sets November 1 to deliver result of five-year case|newspaper =[[The West Australian]] | page=11|date=20 October 2012}}</ref>
The trial judge closely examined evidence on the conduct of Lloyd Rayney and reportedly described him as a barrister who had engaged in "disreputable conduct"<ref>Colleen Egan [http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/15409800/pressure-to-find-rayney-answers/ Pressure to find Rayney answers] ''[[The West Australian]]'', 18 November 2012. Retrieved 25 June 2014 {{dead link|date=March 2017}}</ref> in comments which were [[Redaction|redacted]] from the final official judgment (para 1594), and Justice Martin noted that "The accused has engaged in discreditable conduct including knowingly arranging for illegal telephone interception, making a false declaration and giving deliberately false evidence to a court while on oath. The evidence raises suspicion; in some instances quite strong suspicion. But discreditable conduct does not prove guilt, and suspicion, even strong suspicion, falls well short of proof beyond reasonable doubt."<ref name=full_judgment/> The Judgment Summary further explained: "Evidence concerning such conduct was not admitted to show that the accused is a person of bad character. The fact that the accused engaged in discreditable conduct and could, therefore, be viewed as a person of bad character, cannot be used to reason that the accused is the type of person who might kill his wife, or that by reason of his bad character he is likely to have killed her. Such reasoning would be unfair and is prohibited."<ref>[http://www.supremecourt.wa.gov.au/_files/Judgment_Summary_Rayney.pdf Judgment Summary: The State of Western Australia v Rayney] [No 3] [2012] WASC 404 (INS 83 of 2011) [[Supreme Court of Western Australia]]</ref>
===Appeal dismissed=== An appeal by prosecutors against the verdict was held in the [[Supreme Court of Western Australia]] in August 2013, before three judges brought in from other states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-08-05/names-of-judges-revealed-for-rayney-appeal/4866218?section=wa|title=Prosecutors appealing Lloyd Rayney's murder acquittal want a retrial|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=6 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> The prosecution, if granted leave to appeal, proposed to rely on the grounds that the trial judge's findings in relation to motive were not supported by the facts his Honour found in relation to the respective attitudes of the respondent and the deceased.<ref>[https://jade.io/article/302686] ''The State of Western Australia v Rayney'' [2013] WASCA 219, [7].</ref> The judges unanimously dismissed the appeal, and upheld the trial judge's verdict.<ref>[http://decisions.justice.wa.gov.au/supreme/supdcsn.nsf/PDFJudgments-WebVw/2013WASCA0219/%24FILE/2013WASCA0219.pdf The State Of Western Australia -v- Rayney (2013) Wasca 219 (Appeal judgment)] at [[Supreme Court of Western Australia]], delivered 23 September 2013</ref><ref>[http://decisions.justice.wa.gov.au/supreme/supdcsn.nsf/PDFJudgments-WebVw/2013WASCA0219A/%24FILE/2013WASCA0219A.pdf Appeal Judgment Summary] at [[Supreme Court of Western Australia]], delivered 23 September 2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Kaitlyn|last=Offer|url=http://perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/prosecution-appeal-decision-looms-for-lloyd-rayney/story-fnhocxo3-1226724421937|title=Case dismissed: no retrial for Lloyd Rayney|newspaper=[[Perth Now|Sunday Times]]|date=23 September 2013|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-23/appeal-judges-deliver-verdict-in-appeal-against-rayney27s-acqu/4975132|title=Court dismisses appeal against acquittal of Lloyd Rayney over murder of wife Corryn|publisher=ABC News|date=23 September 2013|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> The office of the [[Director of Public Prosecutions (New South Wales)|NSW Director of Public Prosecutions]], which ran the case, announced on 18 October 2013 that it would not be seeking a further appeal to the [[High Court of Australia|High Court]].<ref name=caseclosed>{{cite news|author = Christiana Jones|title = Case closed for Rayney over murder|newspaper = [[The West Australian|The Weekend West]]| page=15|date=18 October 2013}}</ref> <ref name=sbs>{{cite news|agency = Australian Associated Press|author-link = Australian Associated Press| url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2013/10/18/rayney-murder-case-will-not-be-appealed|title = Rayney murder case will not be appealed|publisher =[[SBS World News]]| date=19 October 2013}}</ref>
===Aftermath=== Mr Rayney indicated interest {{citation needed|reason=Cite your source of indicated interest|date=May 2015}} in whether there would be consequences for "police who the trial judge said gave misleading evidence, pressured a forensic pathologist to change his report, abused their position of authority and behaved reprehensibly".
An investigation by the Western Australian [[Corruption and Crime Commission]] later cleared two police officers of "any serious misconduct" after their behaviour in threatening a female lawyer had been described as ranging from "inappropriate to reprehensible" by the trial judge. A second matter reviewed by the CCC related to "attempts by a third officer to encourage an independent pathologist involved in the case to change a report to better fit police evidence. That officer was found to have acted unreasonably."<ref>"Watchdog clears Rayney cops", ''[[The West Australian]]'', 1 April 2014.</ref>
In May 2015, Rayney was acquitted of two charges of tapping his own residential telephone line.<ref>Joanna Menagh. "[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-07/lloyd-rayney-cleared-after-phone-tapping-trial/6452294 Lloyd Rayney, former Perth barrister, cleared of phone tapping charges]." [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]], 7 May 2015</ref> He is pursuing a multimillion-dollar defamation action against the state over his having been publicly named as "the prime and only suspect".<ref>Tim Clarke. "Rayney back in court." ''[[The West Australian]]'', 21 July 2015.</ref>
In July 2015, Rayney's licence was cancelled by the Legal Practice Board, stripping him of his right to practise law in WA. This action resulted from a finding by a magistrate that he had breached the Surveillance Devices Act by taping conversations with Corryn Rayney, then deliberately disposing of the recording devices when he knew the police had a warrant to search for them.<ref>Tim Clarke. "Lloyd Rayney law licence cancelled". ''[[The West Australian]]'', 5 August 2015</ref> In February 2016, Rayney was cleared by the State Administrative Tribunal of the alleged "unlawful destruction of evidence and/or an attempt to pervert the course of justice" and his right to practise was reinstated.<ref>Kate Campbell. [http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/state-administrative-tribunal-hands-down-decision-on-lloyd-rayneys-legal-career/news-story/60b521dc259c3b10a4212a9ea21bc1c7 State Administrative Tribunal hands down decision on Lloyd Rayney's legal career] ''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]]'', 10 February 2016. Retrieved 18 March 2016</ref> He recommenced his career with the successful defence of an accused drug dealer. The trial was aborted when police evidence was shown to have been unlawfully "destroyed, missing and contradictory".<ref>Amanda Banks. "Rayney returns to win meth case" ''[[The West Australian]]'', 18 March 2016, p. 5</ref>
==Calls for new investigation== In his judgment summary, Justice Martin noted that police and forensic evidence was consistent with a sexual attack on Mrs Rayney,<ref>E.g., see Full Judgment, paragraphs 1454–59,1580–81,1588–90.</ref> while defence lawyers identified at least two possible criminals who "should have been investigated with as much rigour as Mr Rayney".<ref name=hickey31aug>P. Hickey; Emily Moulton. "New charges strengthen case for review", ''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]]'', 31 August 2014, p. 11</ref> In a prime-time TV presentation on 21 August 2014 that was dismissed by Attorney General [[Michael Mischin]] as "infotainment that is one-sided", Rayney, backed by senior lawyers and a forensic scientist, spoke out for the first time and called for independent investigators to re-examine the unsolved case.<ref>Emily Moulton. [http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/lloyd-rayney-breaks-silence-calls-for-coldcase-review-of-wife-corryns-murder/story-fnhocxo3-1227032602390 Lloyd Rayney breaks silence, calls for cold-case review of wife Corryn's murder] PerthNow (''[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|Sunday Times]]''), 21 August 2014. Retrieved 1 September 2014</ref> State Premier [[Colin Barnett]] did not see any need for a review but would await advice from his Attorney General.<ref>Amanda Banks. "[https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/24778227/barnett-cool-on-rayney-investigation/ Barnett cool on Rayney investigation]", ''[[The West Australian]]'', 22 August 2014</ref>
In May 2015, WA Police Commissioner [[Karl O'Callaghan]] ordered a [[cold case]] review of the matter<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-11/commissioner-orders-rayney-cold-case-review/6459330|title=Corryn Rayney murder: Police Commissioner orders cold case review|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|author=Graeme Powell|author2=Courtney Bembridge|date=11 May 2015|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref> which had not resulted in any new charges by March 2017, when a court began hearing Rayney's defamation suit against the state.<ref>Bembridge, Courtney. [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-03-01/lloyd-rayney-defamation-trial-begins/8314074 Lloyd Rayney's reputation suffered after prime suspect comment, defamation trial hears]. ''[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]'', 1 March 2017</ref> Judgment was handed down on 15 December 2017 in favour of Rayney, with final damages to be assessed.<ref>Menagh, Joanna; Carmody, James. [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-12-15/lloyd-rayney-defamation-verdict-handed-down/9259958 Lloyd Rayney wins epic defamation fight against WA Government over Corryn Rayney's death]. [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]], 15 December 2017</ref>

{{Infobox country demographics | country = Sierra Leone | image = | caption = | size_of_population = {{UN_Population|Sierra Leone}} | density = 80.06 inhabitants per sq km. | growth = 15.40% (2004–2014 est.) | birth = 37.40 births/1,000 inhabitants | death = 11.03 deaths/1,000 inhabitants | life = 57.39 years | life_male = 54.85 years | life_female = 60.00 years | infant_mortality = 73.29 deaths/1,000 births | fertility = 4.83 children born/women | age_0–14_years = 41.9% | age_15–64_years = 54.4% | age_65_years = 3.7% | total_mf_ratio = 0.94 male(s)/female | sr_at_birth = 1.03 male(s)/female | sr_under_15 = 0.99 male(s)/female | sr_15–64_years = 0.94 male(s)/female | sr_65_years_over = 0.78 male(s)/female | nation = Sierra Leonean(s) | major_ethnic = Temne 35%, Mende 31% | minor_ethnic = Limba 8%, Kono 5%, Kriole 2%, Mandingo 2%, Loko 2%, other 15% | official = English | spoken = Mende, Temne, Krio }} The '''demographics of [[Sierra Leone]]''' are made up of an indigenous population from 18 ethnic groups. The [[Temne people|Temne]] in the north and the [[Mende people|Mende]] in the South are the largest. About 60,000 are [[Sierra Leone Krio people|Krio]], the descendants of freed slaves who returned to Sierra Leone from [[Great Britain]], [[North America]] and [[Slavery|slave]] ships captured on the high seas. In addition, about 5,000 [[Lebanon|Lebanese]], 1,000 [[India]]ns, and 5,000 [[Europe]]ans reside in the country. In the past, some Sierra Leoneans were noted for their [[education]]al achievements, trading activity, entrepreneurial skills, and arts and crafts work, particularly [[wood carving|woodcarving]]. Many are part of larger ethnic networks extending into several countries, which link West African states in the area. Their level of education and [[infrastructure]] have declined sharply over the last 30 years.{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5475.htm |title=Sierra Leone (02/08) |accessdate=2008-02-17 |work="U.S. Department of State" }} == Population == {{Historical populations |title = Historical populations of Sierra Leone |align = left |shading = off |percentages = pagr |source = {{cite web|url=http://www.sierra-leone.org/Census/ssl_final_results.pdf|format=PDF|title=FINAL RESULTS 2004 POPULATION AND HOUSING CENSUS|website=Sierra-leone.org|accessdate=7 November 2017}} |1963 | 2180355 |1974 | 2735159 |1985 | 3515812 |2004 | 4976871 |2014 | 5743725 }} [[Image:Sierra-Leone-demography.png|thumb|450px|Sierra Leone's total population, from 1961 to 2003.]] According to {{UN_Population|source}} the total population was {{UN_Population|Sierra Leone}} in {{UN_Population|Year}}, compared to only 1 895 000 in 1950. {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Freedom Day |type = |image = Дзень Волі 2018.jpg |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = Дзень Волі |nickname = |observedby = {{flag|Belarus}}, [[Belarusian diaspora]] |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = March 25 |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = Declaration of independence by the [[Belarusian Democratic Republic]] in 1918 |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |scheduling = }} '''Freedom Day''' ({{lang-be|Дзень Волі}}) is an unofficial holiday in [[Belarus]], which is celebrated on March 25 to commemorate the creation of the [[Belarusian Democratic Republic]] on that date in 1918.
[[File:DzenVoli2007.jpg|thumb|250px|right|''Freedom Day'' celebration rally held by the Belarusian opposition in 2007]]
The day has been celebrated as the [[Independence Day (Belarus)|Independence Day of Belarus]] by the Belarusian independence movement since the early 1920s. The day has been widely celebrated by the [[Belarusian diaspora]].
In the United States, governors and US presidents have traditionally issued official greetings to the [[Belarusian American]] community on the occasion of March 25.<ref>[http://www.radabnr.org/?p=2494 BELARUSIAN INDEPENDENCE DAY IN NEW YORK – PROCLAMATION BY MAYOR RUDI GIULIANI]</ref><ref>[http://www.radabnr.org/?p=2173 ANNIVERSARY OF THE BELARUSIAN DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC – GREETING FROM US PRESIDENT BILL CLINTON, 1995]</ref>
In today's [[Belarus]], people and groups largely opposed to the current Belarusian government under president [[Alexander Lukashenko]] celebrate the holiday. The government does not recognize it for the stated reason that the Belarusian Democratic Republic was created by the [[Germany|Germans]], who were occupying Belarus in 1918. Celebrations of the holiday are an annual occasion for anti-government protests.
