A '''microaggression''' is a term used for brief and commonplace daily verbal, behavioural, or environmental indignities, whether intentional or unintentional, that communicate hostile, derogatory, or negative prejudicial slights and insults toward any group.<ref name=":1" /> The term was coined by [[psychiatrist]] and [[Harvard University]] professor [[Chester Middlebrook Pierce|Chester M. Pierce]] in 1970 to describe insults and dismissals which he regularly witnessed non-black Americans inflicting on [[African Americans]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Microaggressions in Everyday Life: Race, Gender, and Sexual Orientation| first = Derald Wing | last = Sue | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Wiley|year=2010|isbn=0-470-49140-X|location=|pages=xvi}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title="Multiplication Is for White People": Raising Expectations for Other People's Children|last=Delpit|first=Lisa | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=The New Press|year=2012|isbn=1-59558-046-8|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Beyond Stereotypes in Black and White: How Everyday Leaders Can Build Healthier Opportunities for African American Boys and Men|last=Treadwell|first=Henrie M.|publisher=Praeger | name-list-format = vanc |year=2013|isbn=1-4408-0399-4|location=|pages=47}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Counseling and Psychotherapy Theories in Context and Practice: Skills, Strategies, and Techniques|last=Sommers-Flanagan|first=Rita | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Wiley|year=2012|isbn=0-470-61793-4|location=|pages=294}}</ref> By the early 21st century, use of the term was applied to the casual degradation of any socially marginalized group, including LGBT, the poor and the disabled.<ref>{{cite book | last = Paludi | first = Michele | name-list-format = vanc | year = 2010 | title = Victims of Sexual Assault and Abuse: Resources and Responses for Individuals and Families (Women's Psychology). | publisher = Praeger | page = 22 | isbn = 0-313-37970-X }}</ref> Psychologist [[Derald Wing Sue]] defines microaggressions as "brief, everyday exchanges that send denigrating messages to certain individuals because of their group membership". The persons making the comments may be otherwise well-intentioned.<ref name="Praege">{{Cite book|title=Managing Diversity in Today's Workplace: Strategies for Employees and Employers|last=Paludi|first=Michele A. | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Praeger|year=2012|isbn=0-313-39317-6|location=|pages=}}</ref>
A number of scholars and social commentators have critiqued the microaggression concept on various grounds, including that it is not well substantiated scientifically, that it is overly dependent on anecdotal evidence, and it assumes without sufficient evidence that slights perceived by the listener or recipient are always due to bias or prejudice. Critics also suggest that avoiding behaviours which may be interpreted as microaggressions restricts freedom and may itself cause emotional distress, and further that this robs both sides of the practice in skills to mediate disputes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Haidt |first1=Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan |title=How Trigger Warnings Are Hurting Mental Health on Campus |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/09/the-coddling-of-the-american-mind/399356/ |website=The Atlantic |accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref> Some suggest that while microaggressions are minor relative to serious offences (e.g. assault), and may be unintentional; they may be abused to exaggerate harm, resulting in disproportionate retribution.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Friedersdorf |first1=Conor |title=Why Critics of the 'Microaggressions' Framework Are Skeptical |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/09/why-critics-of-the-microaggressions-framework-are-skeptical/405106/ |website=The Atlantic |accessdate=2 September 2018 |date=14 September 2015}}</ref> Some of these critics suggest that the concept is not yet developed well enough to be applied in the real world and that its current applications may be harmful to individuals and society.
== Description == Microaggressions have been defined as brief and common daily verbal, behavioral, and environmental communications, whether intentional or unintentional, that transmit hostile, derogatory, or negative messages to a target person because they belong to a stigmatized group.<ref name="Sue, D. 2007" /> Although these communications typically appear harmless to observers, they are considered a form of covert racism or everyday discrimination.<ref name="Kanter 2017" /> Microaggressions differ from what Pierce referred to as “macroaggressions”, which are more extreme forms of racism (such as lynchings or beatings) due to their ambiguity, size and commonality.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pierce |first1=C. |editor1-last=Barbour |editor1-first=F. | name-list-format = vanc |title=In the Black Seventies |date=1970 |publisher=Porter Sargent |location=Boston, MA |page=265-282 |ref=Pierce |chapter=Offensive mechanisms}}</ref> Microaggressions are experienced by most stigmatized individuals and occur on a regular basis. These can be particularly stressful for people on the receiving end as they are easily denied by those committing them. They are also harder to detect by members of the [[dominant culture]],<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Alabi |first1=J. |date=2015 |title=Racial microaggressions in academic libraries: results of a survey of minority and non-minority librarians. |journal=Journal of Academic Librarianship |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=47-53|url=http://aurora.auburn.edu/bitstream/handle/11200/48541/racial%20microaggressions%20in%20the%20academic%20library%20environment_for%20aurora.pdf?sequence=1}}</ref> as they are often unaware they are causing harm.<ref name="Sue, D. 2007" /> Sue describes microaggressions as including statements that repeat or affirm [[Stereotype|stereotypes]] about the minority group or subtly demean its members. Such comments also position the dominant culture as normal and the minority one as aberrant or pathological, express disapproval of or discomfort with the minority group, assume that all minority group members are the same, minimize the existence of discrimination against the minority group, seek to deny the perpetrator's own bias, or minimize real conflict between the minority group and the dominant culture.
=== Categories ===
In conducting two focus groups with [[Asian-Americans]], for instance, Sue proposed eight distinct themes of racial microaggression:<ref name="Sue, D. 2007" /><ref name="sue asian american study">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sue DW, Capodilupo CM, Torino GC, Bucceri JM, Holder AM, Nadal KL, Esquilin M | title = Racial microaggressions in everyday life: implications for clinical practice | journal = The American Psychologist | volume = 62 | issue = 4 | pages = 271–86 | date = 2007 | pmid = 17516773 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066x.62.4.271 }}</ref>
* Alien in own land: When people assume People of Color (POC) are foreigners or from a different country. ** E.g.: "So where are you really from?" or "Why don't you have an accent?" * Ascription of intelligence: When POC are stereotyped as being intelligent or assumed to be at a certain level of intelligence based on their race. ** E.g.: "You people always do well in school." or "If I see a lot of Asian students in my class, I know it's going to be a hard class." * Denial of racial reality: This is when a person emphasizes that a POC does not suffer any discrimination, thus implying they do not face inequality. It correlates to the idea of [[model minority]]. * Exoticization of non-white women: It stereotypes these Americans as being in the "exotic" category. They are stereotyped by their physical appearance and gender based on media and literature. One example is Asian-American women portrayed as the submissive or obedient type; alternatively, they may be portrayed or described as Dragon Lady or Lotus Blossom, using symbols from their cultures. On the other hand, Asian-American men are portrayed as being emasculated or are seen as nerdy, weak men. * Refusal to acknowledge intra-ethnic differences: The homogeneity of broad ethnic groups is emphasized and assumed; the speaker ignores intra-ethnic differences. The focus groups identified the statement that "all Asian-Americans look alike" as a main assumption for this theme. Similarly, thinking that all members of an ethnic minority group speak the same language or have the same values or culture falls under this theme. * Pathologizing cultural values/communication styles: When Asian Americans' cultures and values are viewed as less desirable. For example, many people from the focus groups felt disadvantaged by the expectation in school and higher education of verbal participation in class, when Asian cultural norms value silence. Because of this discrepancy, many Asian-Americans felt that they were being forced to conform to Western cultural norms in order to succeed academically. * Second-class citizenship: This theme emphasizes the idea that People of color are being treated as lesser beings, and are not treated with equal rights or presented as a first priority. ** E.g.: A Korean man walks into a bar and asks for a drink, but the bartender ignores the man when he serves a white man first. * Invisibility: This theme focuses on the idea that Asian Americans are considered invisible or outside discussions of race and racism. According to some focus group members, recent dialogues on race in the United States have often focused only on issues between whites and blacks, excluding Asian-Americans.
In a 2017 peer-reviewed review of the literature, [[Scott Lilienfeld]] critiqued microaggression research for hardly having advanced beyond taxonomies such as the above, which was proposed by Sue nearly ten years ago.<ref name="Lilienfeld2">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lilienfeld SO | title = Microaggressions | journal = Perspectives on Psychological Science | volume = 12 | issue = 1 | pages = 138–169 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 28073337 | doi = 10.1177/1745691616659391 | authorlink = Scott Lilienfeld }}</ref> While acknowledging the reality of "subtle slights and insults directed toward minorities", Lilienfeld concluded that the concept and programs for its scientific assessment are "far too underdeveloped on the conceptual and methodological fronts to warrant real-world application".<ref name="Lilienfeld2" /> He recommended abandonment of the term ''microaggression'' since "the use of the root word 'aggression' in 'microaggression' is conceptually confusing and misleading". In addition, he called for a moratorium on microaggression training programs until further research can develop the field.<ref name="Lilienfeld2" />
In 2017 Althea Nagai, who works as a research fellow at the [[conservative]] [[Center for Equal Opportunity]], published an article criticizing microaggression research as [[pseudoscience]].<ref name="nagai">{{cite journal|last=Nagai|first=Althea|date=9 February 2017|title=The Pseudo-Science of Microaggressions|url=https://www.nas.org/articles/the_pseudo_science_of_microaggressions|journal=Academic Questions|publisher=Springer Nature|volume=30|issue=1|pages=47–57|doi=10.1007/s12129-016-9613-5|issn=0895-4852|name-list-format=vanc}}</ref> Nagai said that the prominent [[Critical race theory|critical race]] researchers behind microaggression theory "reject the methodology and standards of modern science."<ref name="nagai" /> She lists various technical shortcomings of microaggression research, including "biased interview questions, reliance on narrative and small numbers of respondents, problems of reliability, issues of replicability, and ignoring alternative explanations."<ref name="nagai" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/archives/2017/08/02/rutgers-orders-freshmen-to-add-microagre|title=Rutgers Orders Freshmen to Add Microaggression to Their Course Lists|last=Marchello|first=Lindsay|date=August 2, 2017|work=[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]|access-date=August 4, 2017|name-list-format=vanc}}</ref>
=== Race or ethnicity === {{Main|Racism}} Social scientists Sue, Bucceri, Lin, Nadal, and Torino (2007) described microaggressions as "the new face of racism", saying that the nature of racism has shifted over time from overt expressions of [[racial hatred]] and [[hate crime]]s, toward expressions of [[aversive racism]], such as microaggressions, that are more subtle, ambiguous, and often unintentional. Sue says this has led some Americans to believe wrongly that non-white Americans no longer suffer from racism.<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://library.standrews-de.org/lists/courseguides/sas-specific_topic-research/diversity-readings/microaggressions_black.pdf|title = Racial Microaggressions Against Black Americans: Implications for Counseling| first = Derald Wing | last = Sue | name-list-format = vanc |date = Summer 2008|journal = Journal of Counseling & Development|access-date = 11 September 2014|doi = |pmid = |display-authors=etal}}</ref> One example of such subtle expressions of racism is Asian students being either pathologized or penalized as too passive or quiet.<ref name="Sue, D. 2007"/> Another is a teacher correcting a student's use of "indigenous" in a paper by changing it from upper- to lowercase.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/11/25/ucla-grad-students-stage-sit-during-class-protest-what-they-see-racially-hostile|title=UCLA grad students stage sit-in during a class to protest what they see as racially hostile climate|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}}</ref>
According to Sue ''et al''.,<ref name="Sue, D. 2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sue DW, Capodilupo CM, Torino GC, Bucceri JM, Holder AM, Nadal KL, Esquilin M | title = Racial microaggressions in everyday life: implications for clinical practice | journal = The American Psychologist | volume = 62 | issue = 4 | pages = 271–86 | date = 2007 | pmid = 17516773 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066x.62.4.271 }}</ref> microaggressions seem to appear in three forms: * Microassault: an explicit racial derogation; verbal/nonverbal; e.g. name-calling, avoidant behavior, purposeful discriminatory actions. * Microinsult: communications that convey rudeness and insensitivity and demean a person's racial heritage or identity; subtle snubs; unknown to the perpetrator; hidden insulting message to the recipient of color. * Microinvalidation: communications that exclude, negate, or nullify the psychological thoughts, feelings, or experiential reality of a person belonging to a particular group.
Some psychologists have criticized microaggression theory for assuming that all verbal, behavioral, or environmental indignities are necessarily due to bias.<ref name="Lilienfeld">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lilienfeld SO | title = Microaggressions | journal = Perspectives on Psychological Science | volume = 12 | issue = 1 | pages = 138–169 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 28073337 | doi = 10.1177/1745691616659391 | authorlink = Scott Lilienfeld }}</ref><ref name="Thomas">{{cite journal | vauthors = Thomas KR | title = Macrononsense in multiculturalism | journal = The American Psychologist | volume = 63 | issue = 4 | pages = 274–5; discussion 277-9 | date = 2008 | pmid = 18473616 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.63.4.274 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Harris RS | title = Racial microaggression? How do you know? | journal = The American Psychologist | volume = 63 | issue = 4 | pages = 275–6; discussion 277-9 | date = 2008 | pmid = 18473617 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.63.4.275 }}</ref> Thomas Schacht says that it is uncertain whether a behavior is due to racial bias or is a larger phenomenon that occurs regardless of identity conflict.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schacht TE | title = A broader view of racial microaggression in psychotherapy | journal = The American Psychologist | volume = 63 | issue = 4 | pages = 273; discussion 277-9 | date = 2008 | pmid = 18473615 | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.63.4.273 }}</ref> However, Kanter and colleagues found that microaggressions were robustly correlated to five separate measures of bias.<ref name="Kanter 2017" /> In reviewing the microaggression literature, [[Scott Lilienfeld]] suggested that microassaults should probably be struck from the taxonomy because the examples provided in the literature tend not to be "micro", but are outright assaults, intimidation, harassment and bigotry; in some cases, examples have included criminal acts.<ref name="Lilienfeld"/> Others have pointed out that what could be perceived as subtle snubs could be due to people have conditions such as autism or social anxiety disorders and assuming ill will could be harmful to these people.<ref name=eye1 /><ref name=eye2 />
=== Gender === {{Further|Sexism}} Explicit sexism in society is on the decline, but still exists in a variety of subtle and non-subtle expressions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Basford|first=Tessa E.|last2=Offermann|first2=Lynn R.|last3=Behrend|first3=Tara S. | name-list-format = vanc |date=2013-11-19|title=Do You See What I See? Perceptions of Gender Microaggressions in the Workplace |journal=Psychology of Women Quarterly |volume=38|issue=3|pages=340–349 |doi= 10.1177/0361684313511420}}</ref> Women encounter microaggressions in which they are made to feel inferior, sexually objectified, and bound to restrictive gender roles,<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Kaskan|first=Emily R.|last2=Ho|first2=Ivy K.| name-list-format = vanc |title=Microaggressions and Female Athletes|journal=Sex Roles|volume=74|issue=7-8|pages=275–287|doi=10.1007/s11199-014-0425-1}}</ref> both in the workplace and in academia, as well as in athletics.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ross-Sheriff|first=Fariyal | name-list-format = vanc |title=Microaggression, Women, and Social Work|journal=Affilia|volume=27|issue=3|pages=233–236|doi=10.1177/0886109912454366}}</ref> Microaggressions based on gender are applied to female athletes when: their abilities are compared only to men, they are judged on "attractiveness", and individuals are restricted to or requested to wear "feminine" or sexually attractive attire during competition.<ref name=":2" />
Gendered microaggressions and more overt aggression can also be found in violent rape pornography.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Makin DA, Morczek AL | title = X Views and Counting: Interest in Rape-Oriented Pornography as Gendered Microaggression | journal = Journal of Interpersonal Violence | volume = 31 | issue = 12 | pages = 2131–55 | date = July 2016 | pmid = 25724876 | doi = 10.1177/0886260515573572 }}</ref>
Other examples of sexist microaggressions are "[addressing someone by using] a sexist name, a man refusing to wash dishes because it is 'women's work,' displaying nude pin-ups of women at places of employment, someone making unwanted sexual advances toward another person".<ref>{{cite book |last=Wing |first=D. W. | name-list-format = vanc |date=2010 |title=Microaggressions in Everyday Life: Race, Gender, and Sexual Orientation |location=Hoboken |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |page=169 |isbn=978-0-470-49140-9 |oclc=430842664}}</ref>
=== Sexuality and sexual orientation === {{See also|Transphobia|Homophobia|Biphobia|Heterophobia}}
In [[focus group]]s, individuals identifying as [[bisexual]] report such microaggressions as others denying or dismissing their self-narratives or identity claims, being unable to understand or accept bisexuality as a possibility, pressuring them to change their bisexual identity, expecting them to be sexually promiscuous, and questioning their ability to maintain [[monogamy|monogamous]] relationships.<ref name="Bostwick">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bostwick W, Hequembourg A | title = 'Just a little hint': bisexual-specific microaggressions and their connection to epistemic injustices | journal = Culture, Health & Sexuality | volume = 16 | issue = 5 | pages = 488–503 | pmid = 24666221 | doi = 10.1080/13691058.2014.889754 }}</ref> [[Transgender]] people classify being labelled as being of a gender other than the one with which they identify as an example of microaggression.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women and Management: Global Issues and Promising Solutions|last=Paludi|first=Michele A. | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Praeger|year=2013|isbn=0-313-39941-7|location=|pages=237}}</ref>
Some [[LGBT]] individuals report receiving expressions of microaggression from people even within the [[LGBT community]].<ref name="Roffee Waling pp. 190–201"/> They say that being excluded, or not being made welcome or understood within the gay and lesbian community is a microaggression.<ref name="Bostwick"/> Roffee and Waling suggest that the issue arises, as occurs among many groups of people, because a person often makes assumptions based on individual experience, and when they communicate such assumptions, the recipient may feel that it lacks taking the second individual into account and is a form of microaggression.<ref name="Roffee Waling pp. 190–201">{{cite journal | last=Roffee | first=James A. | last2=Waling | first2=Andrea | name-list-format = vanc | year=2016 | title=Rethinking microaggressions and anti-social behaviour against LGBTIQ+ youth | journal=Safer Communities | publisher=Emerald | volume=15 | issue=4 | issn=1757-8043 | pages=190–201 | doi=10.1108/sc-02-2016-0004}}</ref>

=== People with mental illnesses === {{Further|Disability abuse}} People with mental illness report receiving more overt forms of microaggression than subtle ones, coming from family and friends as well as from authority figures.<ref name=Gonzales/> In a study involving college students and adults who were being treated in community care, five themes were identified: invalidation, assumption of inferiority, fear of mental illness, shaming of mental illness, and being treated as a second-class citizen.<ref name=Gonzales>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gonzales L, Davidoff KC, Nadal KL, Yanos PT | title = Microaggressions experienced by persons with mental illnesses: An exploratory study | journal = Psychiatric Rehabilitation Journal | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 234–41 | date = September 2015 | pmid = 25402611 | doi = 10.1037/prj0000096 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/268450566_Microaggressions_Experienced_by_Persons_With_Mental_Illnesses_An_Exploratory_Study }}</ref>
=== Media === Members of marginalized groups have also described microaggressions committed by performers or artists associated with various forms of media, such as television, film, photography, music, and books. Some researchers believe that such cultural content reflects but also molds society,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Pierce|first=Chester M.|last2=Carew|first2=Jean V.|last3=Pierce-Gonzalez|first3=Diane|last4=Wills|first4=Deborah| name-list-format = vanc |title=An Experiment in Racism|journal=Education and Urban Society|volume=10|issue=1|pages=61–87|doi=10.1177/001312457701000105}}</ref> allowing for unintentional bias to be absorbed by individuals based on their media consumption, as if it were expressed by someone with whom they had an encounter.
A study of racism in TV commercials describes microaggressions as gaining a cumulative weight, leading to inevitable clashes between races due to subtleties in the content.<ref name=":3"/> As an example of a racial microaggression, or microassault,<ref name="Sue, D. 2007"/> this research found that black people were more likely than white counterparts to be shown eating or participating in physical activity, and more likely to be shown working for, or serving others.<ref name=":3"/> The research concludes by suggesting that microaggressive representations can be omitted from a body of work, without sacrificing creativity or profit.
Pérez Huber and Solorzano<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pérez Huber|first=Lindsay|last2=Solorzano|first2=Daniel G.| name-list-format = vanc |title=Visualizing Everyday Racism|journal=Qualitative Inquiry|volume=21|issue=3|pages=223–238|doi=10.1177/1077800414562899}}</ref> start their analysis of microaggressions with an anecdote about Mexican "bandits" as portrayed in a children's book read at bedtime. The article gives examples of negative stereotypes of Mexicans and Latinos in books, print, and photos, associating them with the state of racial discourse within majority culture and its dominance over minority groups in the US. The personification of these attitudes through media can also be applied to microaggressive behaviors towards other marginalized groups.
A 2015 review of the portrayal of LGBT characters in film <!-- covering what time span and in what country? what types of film? --> says that gay or lesbian characters are presented in "offensive" ways.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Stein|first=Peter L. | name-list-format = vanc |date=November-December 2015|title=A cinematic trend emerges: 'gays gone bad'|journal=The Gay & Lesbian Review Worldwide|volume=22 (6)|pages=|via=Gale Literature Resource Center|url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/9c5bb0f3946732f36afcf10f450b0c1e/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=45917}}</ref> In contrast, LGBT characters portrayed as complex characters who are more than a cipher for their sexual orientation or identity are a step in the right direction. Ideally, "queer film audiences finally have a narrative pleasure that has been afforded to straight viewers since the dawn of film noir: a central character who is highly problematical, but fascinating."<ref name=":4"/>
=== Ageism and intolerance === Microaggression can target and marginalize any definable group, including those who share an age grouping or belief system. Microaggression is a manifestation of bullying that employs micro-linguistic power plays in order to marginalize any target with a subtle manifestation of intolerance by signifying the concept of "other".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gendron |first1=Tracey L. |last2=Welleford |first2=E. Ayn |last3=Inker |first3=Jennifer |last4=White |first4=John T. | name-list-format = vanc |title=The Language of Ageism: Why We Need to Use Words Carefully |journal=The Gerontologist |date=December 2016 |volume=56 |issue=6 |pages=997–1006 |doi=10.1093/geront/gnv066}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = 5 Microaggressions Secular People Often Hear – And Why They're Wrong | first = Miri | last = Mogilevsky | name-list-format = vanc | work = Everyday Feminism | date = 4 June 2016 | access-date = 5 May 2017 | url = http://everydayfeminism.com/2016/06/microaggressions-against-secular-people/ }}</ref>
== Perpetrators ==
Because perpetrators may be well-meaning and microaggressions are subtle, the recipients often experience [[attributional ambiguity]], which may lead them to dismiss the event and blame themselves as overly sensitive to the encounter.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Internalized Oppression: The Psychology of Marginalized Groups|last = David|first = E.J.R. | name-list-format = vanc |publisher = Springer Publishing Company|year = 2013|isbn = 0-8261-9925-9|location = |pages = 5}}</ref> If challenged by the minority person or an observer, perpetrators will often defend their microaggression as a misunderstanding, a joke, or something small that should not be blown out of proportion.<ref name="Love" />
== Effects ==
A 2013 scholarly review of the literature on microaggressions concluded that "the negative impact of racial microaggressions on psychological and physical health is beginning to be documented; however, these studies have been largely correlational and based on recall and self-report, making it difficult to determine whether racial microaggressions actually cause negative health outcomes and, if so, through what mechanisms".<ref name="wong">{{cite journal|vauthors=Wong G, Derthick AO, David EJ, Saw A, Okazaki S|date=June 2014|title=How: A Review of Racial Microaggressions Research in Psychology|journal=Race and Social Problems|volume=6|issue=2|pages=181–200|doi=10.1007/s12552-013-9107-9|pmc=4762607|pmid=26913088}}</ref> A 2017 review of microaggression research pointed out that as scholars try to understand the possible harm caused by microaggressions, they have not conducted much cognitive or behavioural research, nor much experimental testing, and they have overly relied on small collections of anecdotal testimonies from samples who are not representative of any particular population.<ref name="Lilienfeld" />
Recipients of microaggressions may feel anger, frustration, or exhaustion. African-Americans have reported feeling under pressure to "represent" their group or to suppress their own cultural expression and "act white".<ref name="Sue, D. 2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sue D, Capodilupo CM, Holder AM | year = 2008 | url = https://nature.berkeley.edu/garbelottoat/wp-content/uploads/sue2008.pdf | title = Racial microaggressions in the life experience of black Americans | journal = Professional Psychology: Research and Practice | volume = 39 | pages = 329–336 }}</ref> Over time, the cumulative effect of microaggressions is thought by some to lead to diminished [[self-confidence]] and a poor [[self-image]] for individuals, and potentially also to such mental-health problems as depression, anxiety, and trauma.<ref name="Love">{{cite thesis | degree = Ph.D. |title = An Emancipatory Study with African-American Women in Predominantly White Nursing Schools|last = Love|first = Katie Lynn | name-list-format = vanc |publisher = University of Connecticut |year = 2009|isbn = |location = |pages = 221|url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/72975e56514073eb23b5679f036b7cd1/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750&diss=y}}</ref><ref name="Sue, D. 2008" /><ref name="Evans">{{Cite book|title = African Americans and Community Engagement in Higher Education: Community Service, Service-learning, and Community-based Research|last = Evans|first = Stephanie Y. | name-list-format = vanc |publisher = State University of New York Press|year = 2009|isbn = 1-4384-2874-X|location = |pages = 126–127}}</ref><ref name="Lundberg">{{Cite book|title = Women and Mental Disorders|last = Lundberg|first = Paula K. | name-list-format = vanc |publisher = Praeger|year = 2011|isbn = 0-313-39319-2|location = |pages = 89–92}}</ref> Many researchers have argued that microaggressions are more damaging than overt expressions of bigotry precisely because they are small and therefore often ignored or downplayed, leading the victim to feel self-doubt for noticing or reacting to the encounter, rather than justifiable anger, and isolation rather than support from others about such incidents.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Greer | first=Tawanda M | last2=Chwalisz | first2=Kathleen | name-list-format = vanc | title=Minority-Related Stressors and Coping Processes Among African American College Students | journal=Journal of College Student Development | publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press | volume=48 | issue=4 | year=2007 | pages=388–404 | url=https://doi.org/10.1353/csd.2007.0037 | doi=10.1353/csd.2007.0037 | access-date=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Solórzano |first1=Daniel |last2=Ceja |first2=Miguel |last3=Yosso |first3=Tara | name-list-format = vanc |title=Critical Race Theory, Racial Microaggressions, and Campus Racial Climate: The Experiences of African American College Students | work=Journal of Negro Education |volume=69 |number=1 |date=2000 |p=60–73 | jstor=2696265}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Watkins |first1=Nicole L. |last2=Labarrie |first2=Theressa L. |last3=Appio |first3=Lauren M. | name-list-format = vanc |chapter=Black undergraduates’ experience with perceived racial microaggressions in predominantly White colleges and universities |p=25–58 |editor-last=Sue | editor-first=D.W. | title=Microaggressions and Marginality: Manifestation, Dynamics, and Impact | publisher=Wiley | year=2010 | isbn=978-0-470-62720-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7WZxpPnnjzkC | access-date=11 April 2017}}</ref> Studies have found that in the U.S. when people color perceived microaggressions from mental health professionals, client satisfaction with therapy is lower.<ref name="constantine 2007">{{cite journal|last1=Constantine|first1=Madonna G. | Psychology|date=2007|volume=54|issue=1|pages=1–16|doi=10.1037/0022-0167.54.1.1 }}</ref><ref name="Owen 2014">{{cite journal |last1=Owen |first1=Jesse |last2=Tao |first2=Karen W. |last3=Imel |first3=Zac E. |last4=Wampold |first4=Bruce E. |last5=Rodolfa |first5=Emil | name-list-format = vanc |title=Addressing racial and ethnic microaggressions in therapy. |journal=Professional Psychology: Research and Practice |date=2014 |volume=45 |issue=4 |pages=283–290 |doi=10.1037/a0037420}}</ref> Some studies suggest that microaggressions represent enough of a burden that some people of color may fear, distrust, and/or avoid relationships with white people in order to evade such interaction.<ref name="Evans" /> On the other hand, some people report that dealing with microaggressions has made them more resilient.<ref name="Lundberg" /> Scholars have suggested that, although microaggressions "might seem minor", they are "so numerous that trying to function in such a setting is 'like lifting a ton of feathers.{{'"}}<ref>{{Cite web|title = Harvard Study Suggests Microaggressions Might Make People Die Sooner|url = http://www.nationalreview.com/article/396306/harvard-study-suggests-microaggressions-might-make-people-die-sooner-katherine-timpf|access-date = 2015-09-10}}</ref>
==Criticism==
=== Public discourse and harm to speakers ===
<!-- This paragraph needs a good opening line to summarize; it's a bit of a hodge-podge --> Kenneth R. Thomas claimed in ''[[American Psychologist]]'' that recommendations inspired by microaggression theory, if "implemented, could have a chilling effect on free speech and on the willingness of White people, including some psychologists, to interact with people of color."<ref name="Thomas"/> Sociologists Bradley Campbell and Jason Manning have written in the academic journal ''Comparative Sociology'' that the microaggression concept "fits into a larger class of conflict tactics in which the aggrieved seek to attract and mobilize the support of third parties" that sometimes involves "building a case for action by documenting, exaggerating, or even falsifying offenses".<ref name="campbell" /> The concept of microaggressions has been described as a symptom of the breakdown in civil discourse, and that microaggressions are "yesterday's well-meaning faux pas".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Demetriou |first1=Dan |chapter=Fighting Together: Civil Discourse and Agonistic Honor|title= Honor in the Modern World: Interdisciplinary Perspectives |editor-first1 = Laurie | editor-last1 = Johnson | editor-first2 = Dan | editor-last2 = Demetriou | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Lexington Books |year=<!-- unpublished --> |isbn= |url=http://philpapers.org/rec/DEMFTC|access-date=4 June 2016}}</ref>
One suggested type of microaggression by an Oxford University newsletter was avoiding eye contact or speaking directly to people. This spurred a controversy when it was pointed out that such assumptions are insensitive to autistic people who may have trouble making eye contact.<ref name=eye1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-39742670|title=Oxford sorry for eye contact racism claim|date=2017-04-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=eye2>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2017/04/29/oxford-university-apologises-everyday-racism-advice-offended/|title=Oxford University apologises for 'everyday racism' advice which offended autistic people|last=Turner|first=Camilla|date=2017-04-29|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
=== Culture of victimhood ===
In their article "[[Microaggression and Moral Cultures]]", sociologists Bradley Campbell and Jason Manning<ref name="campbell">{{cite journal |last=Campbell |first=Bradley |last2=Manning |first2=Jason | name-list-format = vanc |date=2014 |title=Microaggression and Moral Cultures |url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/15691330-12341332 |journal=Comparative Sociology |volume=13 |issue=6 |pages=692–726 |doi=10.1163/15691330-12341332 |access-date=20 September 2015}}</ref> say that the discourse of microaggression leads to a [[Victim mentality|culture of victimhood]]. Social psychologist [[Jonathan Haidt]] states that this culture of victimhood lessens an individual's "ability to handle small interpersonal matters on one's own" and "creates a society of constant and intense moral conflict as people compete for status as victims or as defenders of victims".<ref name="Haidtblog1">{{Cite web | first = Jonathan | last = Haidt | name-list-format = vanc | work = Righteous Mind |title=Where microaggressions really come from: A sociological account|url=http://righteousmind.com/where-microaggressions-really-come-from/|access-date=20 September 2015|quote=The key idea is that the new moral culture of victimhood fosters 'moral dependence' and an atrophying of the ability to handle small interpersonal matters on one's own. At the same time that it weakens individuals, it creates a society of constant and intense moral conflict as people compete for status as victims or as defenders of victims.}}</ref> Similarly, [[John McWhorter]], linguist and social commentator suggests that "it infantilizes black people to be taught that microaggressions, and even ones a tad more macro, hold us back, permanently damage our psychology, or render us exempt from genuine competition."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.the-american-interest.com/2018/07/26/starbucks-and-the-swimming-pool/|title=Starbucks and the Swimming Pool - The American Interest|date=2018-07-26|work=The American Interest|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/32618/microaggression-is-the-new-racism-on-campus/|title='Microaggression' Is the New Racism on Campus|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/03/15/the-privilege-of-checking-white-privilege|title=The Privilege of Checking White Privilege|last=McWhorter|first=John|date=2015-03-15|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}</ref>
=== Emotional distress ===
In ''[[The Atlantic]]'', [[Greg Lukianoff]] and [[Jonathan Haidt]] expressed concern that the focus on microaggressions can cause more emotional trauma than the experience of the microaggressions at the time of occurrence. They believe that self-policing by an individual of thoughts or actions in order to avoid committing microaggressions may cause emotional harm as a person seeks to avoid becoming a microaggressor, as such extreme self-policing may share some characteristics of pathological thinking.<ref name="atlantic">{{Citation|last=Lukianoff|first=Greg|title=''"The Coddling of the American Mind"''|date=September 2015|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/09/the-coddling-of-the-american-mind/399356/|year=|last2=Haidt|first2=Jonathan| name-list-format = vanc |author-link=|author2-link=|publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]''|access-date=14 February 2016}}</ref> Referring especially to prevention programs at schools or universities, they say that the element of protectiveness, of which identifying microaggression allegations are a part, prepares students "poorly for professional life, which often demands intellectual engagement with people and ideas one might find uncongenial or wrong".<ref name=atlantic/> They also said that it has become "unacceptable to question the reasonableness (let alone the sincerity) of someone's emotional state", resulting in adjudication of alleged microaggressions having characteristics of witch trials.<ref name="atlantic"/>
Writing for ''[[The Federalist (website)|The Federalist]]'', Paul Rowan Brian argued that microaggression theory pools trivial and ignorable instances of racism with real, genuine prejudice and exclusion.<ref name="Rowan">{{cite web|url=http://thefederalist.com/2013/12/16/unmasking-mustachioed-menace-microaggression/|title=Unmasking The Mustachioed Menace Of Microaggression | first = Paul Rowan | last = Brian | name-list-format = vanc |date=December 16, 2013|work=The Federalist}}</ref> [[Amitai Etzioni]], writing in ''[[The Atlantic]]'', suggested that attention to microaggressions distracts individuals and groups from dealing with much more serious acts.<ref name="Etzioni">{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2014/04/dont-sweat-the-microaggressions/360278/|work=The Atlantic|title=Don't Sweat the Microaggressions|date=April 8, 2014|first=Amitai|last=Etzioni | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref>
=== Political correctness ===
[[Ralph Nader]] has similarly criticized the concepts of announcement of trigger warnings and political correctness on campuses as creating too much sensitivity.<ref>{{cite news|last1=DePillis|first1=Lydia | name-list-format = vanc |title=An Election Season Conversation With Ralph Nader, the Nation’s No. 1 Public-Interest Crusader|work=Pacific Standard|url=https://psmag.com/election-season-politics-with-ralph-nader-public-interest-crusader-82d6fbd6e13d|access-date=12 June 2016|date=6 June 2016}}</ref> Viv Regan, writing for ''[[Spiked (magazine)|Spiked Online]]'', wondered whether the comfort provided by having a convenient label for alleged rudeness outweighs the damage caused by overreaction.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Regan|first1=Viv | name-list-format = vanc |url=http://www.spiked-online.com/newsite/article/microaggression-desperately-seeking-discrimination1/16407#.VKISZemA8|publisher=Spiked|title= Microaggression: desperately seeking discrimination |date=29 December 2014}}</ref>
According to Derald Wing Sue, whose works popularized the term, many critiques are based on the term being misunderstood or misused. He said that his purpose in identifying such comments or actions was to educate people and not to silence or shame them. He further notes that, for instance, identifying that someone has used racial microaggressions is not intended to imply that they are racist.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Zamudio-Suaréz|first1=Fernanda | name-list-format = vanc |title=What Happens When Your Research Is Featured on ‘Fox & Friends’ |url=http://chronicle.com/article/What-Happens-When-Your/236949|website=The Chronicle of Higher Education|access-date=30 June 2016}}</ref>
