{{For|other uses of the term|Moral policing (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} '''Moral police''' is a blanket term used to describe [[vigilante]] groups which act to enforce a code of morality in [[India]].{{cite news|title=Moral police runs riot in capital|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1100215/jsp/jharkhand/story_12106579.jsp|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[The Telegraph (India)]]|date=15 February 2010}}{{cite news|title=Who will control the vigilantes? Moral policing|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/who-will-control-the-vigilantes-moral-policing/article1334563.ece|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=9 September 2008}} Some of India's laws, and some actions of [[Law enforcement in India|police forces in India]] are also considered to be instances of moral policing. The target of moral policing is any activity that vigilante groups, the government or police deem to be "immoral" and/or "against [[Culture of India|Indian culture]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/indias-moral-police-declare-war-on-decadence/2006/11/10/1162661900519.html |title=India's moral police declare war on decadence |newspaper=[[The Age]] |date=11 November 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/Do-we-need-cops-as-moral-police/articleshow/1621097.cms |title=Do we need cops as moral police? |work= [[The Times of India]] |date=5 June 2006 |accessdate=11 November 2013}} ==Overview== India has several vigilante groups that claim to protect the [[Indian culture]]. They resist and oppose cultural concepts that they deem to have been imported from the [[Western culture]]. They have been known to attack bars and pubs.{{cite news|title='Moral police' attack Mangalore pub|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2009/jan/26sri-ram-sena-attacks-mangalore-pub.htm|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=26 January 2009}} Some of these groups have attacked or have forced to shut down [[art exhibitions]], where they claim obscene paintings were being displayed.{{cite news|title=Art attack: Moral police threaten nudes exhibition|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Art-attack-Moral-police-threaten-nudes-exhibition/articleshow/18342297.cms|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=5 February 2013}}{{cite news|title=Vadodara art student lands in jail|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/vadodara-art-student-lands-in-jail/article1-221807.aspx|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=11 May 2007}} They have issued diktats against western attires.{{cite news|title=Don’t let your daughter wear tight jeans, moral police tell parents in Maharashtra|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-don-t-let-your-daughter-wear-tight-jeans-moral-police-tell-parents-in-maharashtra-1430651|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=30 August 2010}} Some have also condemned [[beauty salon|beauty parlours]].{{cite news|title='Veiled' moral policing in J&K|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2005/aug/30veil.htm|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=31 August 2005}} Some members of the media have also colluded with such groups. Some politicians have supported such viewpoints and occasionally such activities.{{cite news|title=(Im)moral policing|url=http://zeenews.india.com/exclusive/immoral-policing_2223.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Zee News]]|date=7 February 2009}} ==Laws== In India, the Sections 292 to 294 of the [[Indian Penal Code]] are used to deal with obscenity. Most of these laws date back to 1860.{{cite news|title=Who’s afraid of kissing?|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1090218/jsp/opinion/story_10552589.jsp|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The Telegraph (India)]]|date=18 February 2009}} The Section 292 of the Indian Penal Code deals with sales and distribution of obscene books and other material. It criminalises materials like books and paintings if it is deemed to be "lascivious or appeals to the prurient interest".{{cite web|title=The Indian Penal Code, 1860|url=http://chddistrictcourts.gov.in/THE%20INDIAN%20PENAL%20CODE.pdf|publisher=Chandigarh District Courts|accessdate=6 December 2014}} The Section 292 was amended in 1969 to exclude material that are for public good (like condom ads), scientific material, art and religious figures.{{cite book|title=Freedom of the Press: Using the Law to Defend Journalists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cBkNQZT0fLQC&pg=PA39|accessdate=7 December 2014|year=2009|publisher=Socio Legal Information Cent|isbn=978-81-89479-59-6|page=39}} Police also use Section 292 of the IPC to file cases against film posters and advertisement hoardings that are deemed to be "obscene".{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Zeher-poster-makers-face-obscenity-plaint/articleshow/1067343.cms?referral=PM |title='Zeher' poster makers face obscenity plaint |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |work=[[The Times of India]]|date=1 April 2005 |accessdate=11 November 2013}} The Section 293 deals with the sale of obscene material to people under 20. The [[Section 294 of the Indian Penal Code]] deals with "obscene acts and songs" and it states that: {{Cquote|''Whoever, to the annoyance of others'' ''(a) Does any obscene act in any public place, or''
''(b) Sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place,'' ''Shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.''}} There is no proper definition of an obscene act and it is open to interpretation.{{cite news|title=Is kissing in public an obscene act?|url=http://www.livemint.com/Opinion/5DKL9wuITBg8LosTQFFX8O/Is-kissing-in-public-an-obscene-act.html|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[Live Mint]]|date=4 November 2014}} It is frequently used by the police to justify acts of moral policing.{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2005-12-22/india/27851674_1_ipc-obscene-act-public-place |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131006110554/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2005-12-22/india/27851674_1_ipc-obscene-act-public-place |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 October 2013 |title=Loopholes in IPC drive moral police |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=22 December 2005 |accessdate=5 December 2014}} [[Prostitution in India#Immoral Traffic .28Prevention.29 Act - PITA|Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956]] (also known as Prevention of Immoral Traffic Act or PITA) was originally passed to prevent [[human trafficking]].{{cite book|title=Trafficking in Women and Children in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1xFnEyqFupUC&pg=PA194|accessdate=17 December 2014|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-250-2845-1|page=194}} It allows police to raid hotels if they suspect a sex racket is being run there.{{cite news|title=Law and ‘morals’ fox police|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Law-and-morals-fox-police/articleshow/8902646.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=5 May 2002}} Police have used this law to raid hotels and arrest consenting couples.{{cite news|title=Suspecting prostitution, police detain 56 young couples from Ghaziabad hotel|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/suspecting-prostitution-police-detain-56-young-couples-from-ghaziabad-hotel/article1-1106321.aspx|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=10 August 2013}} India's obscenity laws have also been frequently compared to the [[Hicklin test]].{{cite book|author=Girja Kumar|title=The Book on Trial: Fundamentalism and Censorship in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n-KUICFfA00C&pg=PA172|date=1 January 1997|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|isbn=978-81-241-0525-2|pages=172}}{{cite book|author=Inder S. Rana|title=Law of Obscenity in India, USA & UK|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UD8Yq_SrrBQC&pg=PA144|accessdate=7 December 2014|year=1990|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-169-4|page=144}} ==Valentine's Day== {{main article|Valentine's Day in India}} Groups like Shiva Sena, Valentine's Day is often opposed by the moral police for being a western import.{{cite news|last=Mukherjee |first=Krittivas |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2007/05/23/uk-india-intolerance-idUKMOL34834320070523 |title=Cultural bigotry rises as India sees social change |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=23 May 2007|accessdate=11 November 2013}} Vigilante group have been known to attack gift and card shops prior to the occasion.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/2757473.stm |title= Valentine's Day celebrations under fire |work=[[BBC News]] |date=13 February 2003 |accessdate=7 December 2014}} Couples are often beaten up for holding hands or kissing in public. [[Shiv Sena]] leader [[Uddhav Thackeray]] has called it an attack of the west on [[Indian culture]] and that it is attracting youth for commercial gain. [[Shiv Sena]] leader [[Bal Thackeray]] has said that people not wanting violence on the day should not celebrate it.{{cite news|title=Hindu and Muslim anger at Valentine's|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/south_asia/2749667.stm|accessdate=27 January 2015|work=[[BBC News]]|date=11 February 2003}} He has also called the festival shameless and contrary to Indian culture.{{cite news|title=Tough love for Indian Valentines|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1169077.stm|accessdate=27 January 2015|work=[[BBC News]]|date=14 February 2001}} Occasionally, the police also try to restrict these groups but even though their activities flourish till the date.{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/city-cops-turn-moral-police-ahead-of-vday/574377/0 |title=City cops turn moral police ahead of V-Day |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2 February 2010 |accessdate=7 December 2014}} ==Incidents of moral policing== ===By vigilante groups, religious organizations and unaffiliated citizens=== * In the early 1990s, a women's separatist organization called [[Dukhtaran-e-Millat]] in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] began forcing local women to cover their faces and threatening them with [[acid attack]]s.{{cite news|title=Kashmiri women bear the brunt again|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2001/09/14/stories/0214000k.htm|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=14 September 2001}}{{cite news|title=The Burqa Manoeuvre|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/The-Burqa-Manoeuvre/213048|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Outlook India]]|date=3 September 2001}}{{cite news|title=Now Dukhtaran-e-Millat steps in as moral police|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/news/article/Now-DukhtaraneMillat-steps-in-as-moral-police/320066|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Outlook India]]|date=30 August 2005}} During the period, they also attacked cinemas, video parlours, beauty parlours and wine shops. In 2005, they attacked hotel bars and restaurants, and destroyed liquor bottles. * In 1996, a Hindi magazine Vichar Mimansa published an article titled “M. F. Husain: A Painter or a Butcher?” which contained reprints of paintings [[M. F. Husain]] had created in 1975. They depicted various Hindu goddesses in nude or copulating poses. Eight different lawsuits were filed against him.{{cite news|title=Maqbool Fida Husain, India’s Most Famous Painter, Dies at 95|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/arts/design/maqbool-fida-husain-indias-most-famous-painter-dies-at-95.html?ref=deathsobituaries&_r=0|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 June 2011}} In 2008, the Delhi High Court quashed three cases which had been transferred to it.{{cite news|title=Delhi HC quashes obscenity case against MF Husain|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Delhi-HC-quashes-obscenity-case-against-MF-Husain/articleshow/3023286.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=9 May 2008}} * The 1996 [[Miss World]] pageant was held in [[Bangalore]]. It faced criticism from protestors who claimed that event was demeaning women and India's culture. Several self-immolation threats were made. The police arrest 1,500 protestors, including several from the [[BJP]]. One man died in a self-immolation attempt.{{cite news|title=Critic Of Miss World Contest Kills Himself|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-11-15/news/9611150064_1_pageant-critic-protest|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=15 November 1996}}{{cite news|title=Beauty pageant in India becomes a contest of wills|url=http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9611/17/miss.world/index.html|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[CNN]]|date=17 November 1996}}{{cite news|title=Indian police prepare for worst in beauty pageant clash|url=http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9611/22/india.miss.world/|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[CNN]]|date=22 November 1996}}{{cite news|title=Miss World Crowned As Indians Protest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/24/world/miss-world-crowned-as-indians-protest.html|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 November 1996}} Among other organizations which had protested the event were: [[Karnataka Rajya Raitha Sangha]] and [[Communist Party of India]].{{cite news|title=Show of protest: Miss World contest draws flak in Bangalore|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/miss-world-contest-draws-flak-in-bangalore/1/282553.html|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=31 October 1996}} * In 1997, a lawyer named Sabu Thomas from [[Kerala]] filed an obscenity case against the author [[Arundhati Roy]], claiming that the 21st chapter of [[The God of Small Things]] contains obscene scenes.{{cite news|title=A Novelist Beginning With a Bang|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/29/books/a-novelist-beginning-with-a-bang.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 June 1997}} The book was also criticized by politician [[E. M. S. Namboodiripad]].{{cite news|title=EMS attacks literary content of Arundhati Roy's novel|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/nov/29roy.htm|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=29 November 1997}} * In May 2005, [[Nationalist Congress Party]] (NCP) workers stormed a pub in [[Pune]], [[Maharashtra]], broke window panes, and damaged furniture. The move came days after [[Pune Police]] had forced five pubs to shut before the closing time of 12:30 am.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/70139/ |title=Moral police hit Pune nightlife |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=11 May 2011 |accessdate=8 December 2014}} * In September 2005, [[Tamil Nadu|Tamil]] actress [[Kushboo]] said during an interview with a magazine that it was fine for girls to indulge in [[pre-marital sex]] as long as they took precautions against diseases and pregnancies.{{cite news|title=Khushboo's comments stir controversy|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/sep/26khushboo.htm|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=26 September 2005}} Various political parties, notably [[Pattali Makkal Katchi]] and [[Dalit Panther|Dalit Panthers of India]], took offence at the statement.{{cite news|title=Khushboo's sex comment takes political tones|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/oct/06khush.htm|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=6 October 2005}} They claimed that the comment “denigrates the chastity of Tamil Women" and over 20 lawsuits were filed against the actress in the state of Tamil Nadu. During a hearing in November, protestors hurled eggs, rotten tomatoes and slippers at her car.{{cite news|title=Eggs and slippers greet Kushboo|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1051117/asp/nation/story_5486972.asp|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[The Telegraph (India)]]|date=17 November 2005}} In April 2010, the Supreme Court of India dropped all 23 defamation cases against her.{{cite news|title=Supreme Court quashes criminal proceedings against Kushboo|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/supreme-court-quashes-criminal-proceedings-against-kushboo/article413559.ece|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=29 April 2010}} * In September 2005, a [[fatwa]] against tennis player [[Sania Mirza]] was issued by a cleric named Haseeb-ul-hasan Siddiqui of the Sunni Ulema Board. The fatwa said that her attire on the tennis court and billboard advertisements were un-Islamic.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/sep/10/india.randeepramesh|title=Fatwa orders Indian tennis star to cover up|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Guardian (UK)]]|date=10 September 2005}} Mirza later decided to hire bodyguards.{{cite news|title=India's most wanted|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2006/feb/05/features.india|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Guardian (UK)]]|date=5 February 2006}} * In September 2005, a court in [[Rajasthan]] fined an [[Israelis|Israeli]] couple {{currency|1,000|INR}} for kissing during their wedding ceremony. The couple had decided to get married in a Hindu ceremony at [[Pushkar Lake]]. However, the priests were offended when the couple started kissing and hugging during the ceremony, and filed a lawsuit.{{cite news|title=Israelis fined for wedding kiss|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4268058.stm|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 September 2005}} * In December 2006, a obscenity case was filed against [[Rajasthan]] Chief Minister [[Vasundhara Raje]] and [[Biocon]] India Chief [[Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw]] for allegedly kissing at a public function.{{cite news|title=Case against Raje to be heard on Saturday|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Case-against-Raje-to-be-heard-on-Saturday/articleshow/677251.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=1 December 2006}}{{cite news|title=Court to hear obscenity case against Raje, Mazumdar-Shaw|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/court-to-hear-obscenity-case-against-raje-mazumdar-shaw_339399.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Zee News]]|date=2 December 2006}} The lawsuit came after newspapers published the pictures of a cheek-to-cheek [[air kiss]] from a peculiar angle.{{cite news|title=Much ado about air-kissing bad camera angle raises a storm|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2006-12-01/news/27425007_1_channels-picture-friendly-kiss|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The Economic Times]]|date=1 December 2006}} * [[2008 Imphal bombing]]: In October 2008, an explosion occurred at Ragailong, a tribal village near [[Imphal]] where people had gathered to play a traditional [[gambling]] game. Seventeen people were killed, and many more injured, in the blast. The [[Kangleipak Communist Party]] (Military Council) claimed responsibility for the blast, stating they wanted to stop the game because it "affects Manipuri culture adversely".{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1081024/jsp/opinion/story_10009987.jsp |work=[[The Telegraph (India)]]| title=Killing game |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2014}} *[[2009 Mangalore pub attack]]: On 24 January 2009, members of the [[Sri Ram Sena]] barged into the pub "Amnesia — The Lounge" in [[Mangalore]], [[Karnataka]], and beat up a group of young women and men, claiming the women should not be drinking in a public place.{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090622-150075.html|title=Indian students riled by jeans ban|last=Jayaram|first=P.|date=22 June 2009|work=The Straits Times|accessdate=2 December 2014}} * In December 2011, Vinay Rai, the editor of a Delhi-based Urdu daily called Akbari, filed an obscenity case against 21 websites including [[Facebook]], [[Yahoo]] and [[Google]], for allegedly distributing obscene material. The companies appealed the Delhi High Court to drop the case, but the Delhi HC on 13 January allowed the case to proceed.{{cite news|title=The curious case of Vinay Rai|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/the-curious-case-of-vinay-rai/article2893650.ece|accessdate=17 December 2014|work=15 February 2012|date=15 February 2012}} *[[2012 Mangalore homestay attack]]: On 28 July 2012, activists belonging to the Hindu Jagarana Vedike attacked a birthday party at an unlicensed homestay in Mangalore, Karnataka. The 12 people at the party, including 5 girls, were allegedly beaten, stripped and molested. The faces of some girls were blackened. The activists claimed the youngsters were consuming alcohol and were involved in "some indecent activities".{{cite news|title=Mangalore: Girls thrashed for partying, 4 arrested|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/mangalore-girls-thrashed-for-partying-4-arrested/275807-62-129.html|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[IBNLive]]|date=29 July 2012}} * In February 2013, three girls who were members of a rock band in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] began receiving threats and hate messages on the internet. Later, the [[Grand Mufti]] of Kashmir, Bashir-ud-din Farooqi, issued a [[fatwa]] against them, asking them to stop such immoral activities.{{cite news|title=After threats, fatwa issued against Kashmir`s all-girl rock band|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/jammu-and-kashmir/after-threats-fatwa-issued-against-kashmirs-all-girl-rock-band_826901.html|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=[[Zee News]]|date=5 February 2013}} Ayaz Akbar, the spokesperson of [[All Parties Hurriyat Conference]] said that western culture had no place in the Kashmir valley, and [[Dukhtaran-e-Millat]] also supported the fatwa.{{cite news|title=Girl band should be stopped, must abide by sharia: Dukhtaran-e-Millat leader|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/girl-band-should-be-stopped-must-abide-by-sharia-dukhtaranemillat-leader/370937-3-245.html|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=[[IBNLive]]|date=5 February 2013}} Later, the girls shut down the band.{{cite news|title=Muslim Girls Quit Rock Band After National Controversy|url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/05/muslim-girls-quit-rock-band-after-national-controversy/?_r=0|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 February 2013}} * In February 2013, in [[Vatakara]], [[Kozhikode]], a 19-year-old boy died after falling from his two-wheeler. He was trying to escape to group of people chasing him and an under-15 girl with him. The girl was also wounded and was admitted to a hospital.{{cite news|title=Moral policing suspected as boy is killed in chase|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/moral-policing-suspected-as-boy-is-killed-in-chase/article4376964.ece|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=4 February 2013}} * On 23 October 2014, a restaurant in [[Kozhikode]] was attacked and vandalised. The attackers claimed that eatery was facilitating immoral activities.{{cite news|title=‘Moral police’ attack restaurant in Kozhikode|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/kozhikode/moral-police-attack-restaurant-in-kozhikode/article6530107.ece|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=24 October 2014}} The attack came after a local Malayalam-language TV channel broadcast a report claiming that some [[Coffeehouse|coffee shops]] and restaurants in Kozhikode had become centres of “immoral activities”.{{cite news|title=Congress channel alleges ‘immorality’ at Kerala cafe, BJP workers vandalise it|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/congress-channel-alleges-immorality-at-kerala-cafe-bjp-workers-vandalise-it/|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=25 October 2014}} * On 14 July 2015, a [[Madhyamam Daily]] journalist and her husband were attacked by a group at her office. They did not accept that they were married. The police arrived before the incident escalated. Later, a [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] leader was arrested for leading the attack.{{cite news|title=CPI(M) local leader arrested for 'moral police' attack on journalist and husband|url=http://www.thenewsminute.com/article/cpim-local-leader-arrested-moral-police-attack-journalist-and-husband-32216|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=The News Minute}}{{cite news|title=Bid to Attack Journalist, Husband|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/thiruvananthapuram/Bid-to-Attack-JournalistHusband/2015/07/13/article2917258.ece|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[The New Indian Express]]|date=13 July 2015}} ===By police=== * In October 1993, Mumbai police began arresting street-hawkers selling [[girlie magazine]]s. The publishers of ''[[Debonair (magazine)|Debonair]]'' issued a letter to retailers declaring that their magazine was not banned. They petitioned Bombay High Court against seizures of its issues. Another magazine, ''Chastity'', delayed its November issue until it could acquire legal support against seizures.{{cite news|title=The heat is on Bombay police crack whip on obscenity business, give pleasure trade unpleasant fright|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/bombay-police-crack-whip-on-obscenity-business-give-pleasure-trade-unpleasant-fright/1/294804.html|work=[[India Today]]|date=31 December 1994}} * In September 2000, Mumbai police banned kissing in the Marine Drive area. They cited the Section of 110 Mumbai Police Act, 1951 which allows the police to interfere in "disorderly behaviour." The decree was later withdrawn after protests.{{cite news|title=Killing cupid: Thanks to Mumbai Police, Marine Drive no longer a lovers' point|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/thanks-to-mumbai-police-marine-drive-no-longer-a-lovers-point/1/245931.html|accessdate=11 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=25 September 2000}} * In September 2005, the license of a [[Chennai]] night club was suspended by the police, after photographs of some couples kissing were published by two newspapers, [[Tamil Murasu (India)|Tamil Murasu]] and [[Dinamalar]]. The reason for the license suspension was given that the club served alcohol after midnight.{{cite news|title=When in Chennai, don’t kiss or hug|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-when-in-chennai-don-t-kiss-or-hug-4083|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=1 October 2005}} Following the incident, several clubs and bars in the city banned cellphones with cameras.{{cite news|title=Chennai nightclubs lose sleep over camera phones|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-chennai-nightclubs-lose-sleep-over-camera-phones-6939|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=23 October 2005}} * On 19 December 2005, police personnel raided a public park in [[Meerut]], accompanied by cameras crews from TV channels. They attacked couples sitting in the park in front of cameras. The raid was termed “Operation Majnu” (named after the [[Majnu|folklore]]) and it was claimed by the police that the purpose was to check sexual harassment.{{cite news|title=Cops didn’t trip, lovers were target - Operation Majnu: crackdown on couples, not eve-teasers|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1051222/asp/nation/story_5630920.asp|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Telegraph (India)]]|date=21 December 2005}}{{cite news|title=Moral police beat up Meerut girls|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Moral-police-beat-up-Meerut-girls/pmredirectshow/1339622.cms?curpg=1|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=21 December 2005}} * In November 2006, police raided a [[trance music]] festival in [[Jamwa Ramgarh|Ramgarh]] near [[Jaipur]] after local complained about alcohol, drug and sex. They also said that the laser lights at the venue were disturbing the local wildlife.{{cite news|title=India's moral police declare war on decadence|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/indias-moral-police-declare-war-on-decadence/2006/11/10/1162661900519.html|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Age]]|date=11 November 2006}}{{cite news|title=Sex 'overdose' party raided|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Sex-overdose-party-raided/articleshow/360875.cms|accessdate=4 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=6 November 2006}} * In September 2008, a policeman in Delhi filed a case of obscenity against a married couple for kissing in the Dwarka court complex. The couple appealed in the [[Delhi High Court]]. The Court noted that even though the charge-sheet claimed that the case was filed because the passerby were feeling bad, no one was mentioned by name. The Court said that kissing in public by married couples cannot be termed obscene.{{cite news|title=Delhi HC snubs anti-kissing moral police|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/newdelhi/delhi-hc-snubs-anti-kissing-moral-police/article1-374015.aspx|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=3 February 2009}}{{cite news|title=Court notice to Delhi police over couple’s plea|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-newdelhi/court-notice-to-delhi-police-over-couples-plea/article345693.ece|accessdate=3 December 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=3 February 2009}} The Court passed its verdict on 25 May 2009 and asked the police to drop the case against the couple. The police was asked to pay {{currency|5,000|INR}} to both husband and wife.{{cite court|litigants =A & B v. State Thr. N.C.T. of Delhi & Anr. |vol = |reporter = |opinion = |pinpoint = |court = [[Delhi High Court]]|date = 25 May 2009|url=http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/SMD/judgement/27-05-2009/SMD25052009CRLMM2832009.pdf }} * In January 2008, the police from [[D.N. Nagar]] of [[Mumbai]] arrested a [[Belgian]] fashion photographer named Vandelanotte Gaetan for taking nude pictures of two Indian models, Tushar Narvekar and Nitin Gupta.{{cite news|title=Year-long trauma for shooting nude pictures|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/mumbai/cover-story/Year-long-trauma-for-shooting-nude-pictures/articleshow/15898874.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Mumbai Mirror]]|date=19 February 2009}} A court discharged him in March 2009 saying a laptop is akin to a personal diary and photos stored on it cannot used as evidence of obscenity.{{cite news|title=Nude pics on laptop no grounds for obscenity|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/mumbai/others/Nude-pics-on-laptop-no-grounds-for-obscenity/articleshow/15902938.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Mumbai Mirror]]|date=4 March 2009}} * In August 2008, 22 customs officers were arrested from a party at a bungalow near [[Lonavla]]. They were allegedly watching porn on a laptop and were undressed. The police also arrested 10 girls and a husband-wife duo.{{cite news|title=22 Mumbai customs officials arrested|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-22-mumbai-customs-officials-arrested-1186147|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=27 August 2008}} The Mumbai High Court dropped the case in September 2010 stating watching pornography in a private residence is not an offence.{{cite news|title=Watching porn at home isn’t obscenity: Bombay high court|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-watching-porn-at-home-isn-t-obscenity-bombay-high-court-1471681|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=25 November 2010}} * On 29 November 2011, the [[Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh|Ghaziabad]] police launched its own "Operation Majnu". The police caught couples in parks and made the men do sit-ups in front of TV cameras. The head of the operation an officer called Alka Pandey said it was to prevent "innocent girls being trapped by boys with evil motives".{{cite news|title=Love under siege: Cops harass couples in parks in Ghaziabad|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Love-under-siege-Cops-harass-couples-in-parks-in-Ghaziabad/articleshow/10923488.cms|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=30 November 2011}} * In 2012, Assistant Police Commissioner [[Vasant Dhoble]] carried out a series of raids on bars and clubs in and around Mumbai, claiming to rescue prostitutes.{{cite news|title=Mumbai partygoers fear police chief on moral crusade|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/19/mumbai-police-chief-moral-crusade|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Guardian (UK)]]|date=19 July 2012}} In one instance, he labelled four German women wrongly as sex workers in front of cameras when he arrested them on 30 March 2014 from the Voodoo pub.{{cite news|title=Dhoble wrongly detained German women from pub|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/news-archive/web/dhoble-wrongly-detained-german-women-from-pub-2/|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=30 June 2012}} On 5 June 2012, Dhoble raided Masala Curry restaurant after he felt suspicious of women being allowed free entry.{{cite news|title=Mumbai's Night Raider|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mumbai-acp-dhoble-raids-nightclubs-lables-girls-as-prostitutes/1/200858.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=16 June 2012}} Two cousins who were picked up in the raid later filed a defamation case against Dhoble.{{cite news|title=Defamation case against Mumbai top cop Vasant Dhoble: High Court order expected today|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/defamation-case-against-mumbai-top-cop-vasant-dhoble-high-court-order-expected-today-233305|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[NDTV]]|date=19 June 2012}} * On 10 August 2013, [[Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh|Ghaziabad]] police raided a hotel on a tip-off and detained 56 adult couples. It was later found out of them, 52 couples were married or consenting friends. The police had carried out the raid after locals noticed usual traffic to the hotel and told the police.{{cite news|title=Police eats its own words, says there was only sex, no racket in Ghaziabad hotel|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/only-sex-no-racket-in-hotel-ghaziabad-police-hotel/1/299035.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=11 August 2013}} * Following the [[gang rape]] of a photojournalist in [[Mumbai]] in August 2013, Mumbai Police Commissioner Satyapal Singh was severely criticized by the public for defending moral policing.{{cite news|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2013/aug/280813-mumbai-commissioner-of-police-satyapal-singh-controversial-comments-public-ire.htm |title=Top cop Satyapal Singh attracts public ire with for his comments during TV interview |work=[[Mid Day]] |date=28 August 2013 |accessdate=11 November 2011}} The Commissioner was quoted to have said, "On the one hand you want to have a promiscuous culture and on the other hand you want a safe and secure environment for the people."{{cite news|date=28 August 2013 |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-08-28/news/41538769_1_satyapal-singh-mumbai-police-police-commissioner |title=Photojournalist rape: Mumbai ? police commissioner Satyapal Singh 'promiscuous' comment sparks ire|work= [[The Economic Times]] |accessdate=3 December 2014}} * [[Hyderabad Police]] raided a gay party at a club in the city on 3 September 2013. The police defended that raid under the Sector 294 of IPC that it was obscenity in a public place and that bar was serving alcohol after closing time.{{cite news|title=Gay party busted in Begumpet|url=http://archives.deccanchronicle.com/130903/lifestyle-relationship/article/gay-party-busted|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Deccan Chronicle]]|date=3 September 2013}} [[LGBT]] activists denounced the raid as "a classic example of moral policing" and discrimination against the LGBT community.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/raid-on-gay-party-an-act-of-moral-policing-say-activists/article5094130.ece |title=Raid on gay party an act of moral policing, say activists |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=3 September 2013|accessdate=7 December 2014}} * On 14 February 2014, the police in [[Gokarna, India|Gokarna]] attacked a party of about 200 foreigners with sticks. The police claimed that the party was going on after established time limit.{{cite news|title=200 foreigners accuse Gokarna cops of brutal assault at V-Day party|url=http://www.bangaloremirror.com/bangalore/cover-story/200-foreigners-accuse-Gokarna-cops-of-brutal-assault-at-V-Day-party/articleshow/30633255.cms|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Bangalore Mirror]]|date=19 February 2014}} The victims alleged that initially the police had demanded bribes to let the party continue, but attacked them after they refused. A petition was sent to various embassies to interfere in the matter.{{cite news|title=Karnataka Police thrash foreigners for partying beyond permissible time|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/karnataka-police-thrash-foreigners-for-partying-beyond-permissible-time/1/345069.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=23 February 2014}} * On 6 August 2015, [[Malvan region|Malwani]] police in [[Mumbai]], raided hotels and guest houses near [[Aksa Beach]] and [[Madh Island]], and detained about 40 couples. Most of them were consenting couples in private rooms, but they were charged under Section 110 (Indecent behaviour in public) of the Bombay Police Act and fined {{INRConvert|1200}}.{{cite news|title=Mumbai: Couples picked up from hotel rooms, charged with 'public indecency'|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/mumbai-couples-picked-up-from-hotel-rooms-charged-with-public-indecency/16437186|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[Mid Day]]|date=8 August 2015}} Only three cases were filed under [[Prostitution in India#Immoral Traffic .28Prevention.29 Act - PITA|Prevention of Immoral Traffic Act]]. Later, Mumbai Police Commissioner Rakesh Maria order an inquiry into the raids.{{cite news|title=Mumbai Police Hotel Raid: Commissioner Rakesh Maria orders probe into alleged moral policing|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-mumbai-police-hotel-raid-commissioner-rakesh-maria-orders-probe-into-alleged-moral-policing-2112723|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[DNA India]]|date=9 August 2015}} ===By the Central and state governments=== ====Central Board of Film Certification==== {{main article|Central Board of Film Certification|List of films banned in India}} The [[Central Board of Film Certification]] (CBFC) or the Censor Board, which is tasked with regulating the public exhibition of films under the provisions of the "Cinematograph Act, 1952", has been accused of moral policing by some filmmakers. Director [[Anurag Kashyap]] has argued that it is infeasible to have a single body for a large and diverse country like India.{{cite news|title=Censor board or moral police?|url=http://www.mid-day.com/opinion/2011/sep/090911-moral-police-Censor-board-Anurag-Kashyap.htm|accessdate=23 February 2014|newspaper=[[Mid Day]]|date=9 September 2009|author=Shubha Shetty-Saha|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007050553/http://www.mid-day.com/opinion/2011/sep/090911-moral-police-Censor-board-Anurag-Kashyap.htm|archivedate=7 October 2013}} Director [[Prakash Jha]] has pointed out that even if a film is certified by the Board, it is often not allowed a release in some states due to protests from local political parties or moral police. He has also said that the Board should be scrapped and each film-maker should simply state the type of content in the film because the society is mature enough to understand it.{{cite news|title=What ails the Indian Censor Board?|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/what-ails-the-indian-censor-board/15534160|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Mid Day]]|date=16 August 2014}} [[Sudhir Mishra]] has noted that censor committees have been influenced to giving films lighter ratings. The former chief of the Censor Board, [[Sharmila Tagore]], has defended the body saying that it does not carried out moral policing.{{cite news|title=Censor Board not for moral policing: Sharmila Tagore|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/129508/censor-board-not-moral-policing.html|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[Deccan Herald]]|date=15 January 2011}} In August 2014, then chief of the Censor Board, Rakesh Kumar, was arrested for allegedly delaying certifications to films and demanding bribes to speed up the process.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/CBI-arrests-censor-board-CEO-Rakesh-Kumar-for-taking-bribe/articleshow/40379497.cms|title=CBI arrests censor board CEO Rakesh Kumar for taking bribe|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=18 August 2014}} ====Restrictions on night life and alcohol==== {{see also|Prohibition in India}} Throughout India, restrictions have been place by some [[State governments of India|state governments]] on timings for pubs, bars and other establishments that sell liquor.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/india-assumes-the-moral-position/2005/11/25/1132703377098.html |title=India assumes the moral position |work=[[The Age]] |date=25 November 2005|accessdate=7 December 2014}} * The 2005 ban on [[dance bar]]s in [[Maharashtra]] was considered to be an act of moral policing. Prior to the ban, the state government had claimed that the bars had a "corrupting influence on youth and compromised the moral standards of local men". As a result of the ban thousands of women employed by the 750 bars in the state lost their jobs and many were forced into prostitution. In June 2011, the state raised the legal age of drinking to 25, from previous 21.{{cite news|title=Maharashtra raises age for consumption of hard liquor to 25|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/maharashtra-raises-age-for-consumption-of-hard-liquor-to-25/article2068901.ece|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=2 June 2011}} Furthermore, an old law called "Bombay Prohibition of Foreign Liquor Act, 1949", mandates anyone seeking to buy, possess or consume alcohol to obtain a special permit.{{cite news|title=PIL urges scrapping of ‘archaic’ and ‘superfluous’ liquor permit system in Maharashtra|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/PIL-urges-scrapping-of-archaic-and-superfluous-liquor-permit-system-in-Maharashtra/articleshow/39898075.cms|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=8 August 2014}} * The state of [[Karnataka]] has a law dating back to 1967, called Rule 11(1) of the "Karnataka Excise Licences Rules of 1967", which prohibits dancing in establishments which serve alcohol. In July 2014, the [[Karnataka High Court]] asked the government of amend the law, stating that it was unconstitutional as it violated the [[Freedom of Expression]].{{cite news|title=Reverse Ban on Dancing in Bars, HC Tells State Govt|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/Reverse-Ban-on-Dancing-in-Bars-HC-Tells-State-Govt/2014/07/10/article2323287.ece|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[The New Indian Express]]|date=10 July 2014}} This law had been used by the local police to ban dancing in bars and clubs, especially in [[Bangalore]].{{cite news|title=Is Bangalore right about its right to dance?|url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/blogs/thewatercooler/bangalore-dance-103114787.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|work=[[Yahoo News]]|date=26 September 2011}} ====Opposition to sex education in schools==== The Adolescence Education Programme (AEP) was a [[Sex education in India|sex education]] program designed by the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)]] and [[National AIDS Control Organisation]] (NACO) to implement the policies of the National AIDS Control Programme II (NACP II).{{cite web|title=Adolescence Education Programme (AEP)|url=http://naco.gov.in/NACO/Quick_Links/Youth/School_Age_Education_Program_SAEP/|publisher=[[National AIDS Control Organisation]]}} However, it faced opposition in various states, including [[Gujarat]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Karnataka]], and [[Rajasthan]].{{cite news|title=Sex education curriculum angers Indian conservatives|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/24/world/asia/24iht-letter.1.5851113.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 March 2007}} * In February 2007, [[Gujarat]] government in a press release stated that it would not be introducing sex education in the state. It stated that the books suggested in the program by the Central government were inappropriate for children.{{cite news|title=No more sex education in Gujarat schools|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/No-more-sex-education-in-Gujarat-schools/articleshow/1634848.cms|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=18 February 2007}} However, in April 2010, it reintroduced sex education in a diluted form.{{cite news|title=Gujarat introduces ‘improvised’ module for sex education|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/gujarat-introduces--improvised--module-for-sex-education/610528/|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=24 April 2010}} * In March 2007, [[Maharashtra]] government banned sex education in schools.{{cite news|title=Maharashtra resorts to another ban|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-opinion/maharashtra-resorts-to-another-ban/article1822059.ece|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=2 April 2007}} The ban came after the ruling and opposition [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (India)|Members of the Legislative Assembly]] protested in the state assembly claiming that western countries had forced the Central government to implement the program.{{cite news|title=No sex education please, it corrupts, and this is Maharashtra|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/no-sex-education-please-it-corrupts-and-this-is-maharashtra/27130/0|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=31 March 2007}} * In April 2007, the [[Karnataka]] Minister for Primary and Secondary Education Basavaraj Horatti said that the program has been put on hold after complaints from teachers. The teachers had complained that the books was oriented towards increasing the sales of condoms, and that the illustrations were against Indian culture and sexually provocative.{{cite news|title=No sex education in Karnataka schools now: Minister|url=http://www.oneindia.com/2007/04/18/no-sex-education-in-karnataka-schools-now-minister-1176893759.html|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=One India|date=18 April 2007}} * In May 2007, [[Madhya Pradesh]] Chief Minister [[Shivraj Singh Chouhan]] banned sex education in schools claiming that [[sex education]] has no place in [[Indian culture]].{{cite news|title=Madhya Pradesh bans sex education|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/madhya-pradesh-bans-sex-education/25871/|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=17 March 2007}} * In May 2007, [[Rajasthan]] Chief Minister [[Vasundhara Raje]] wrote a letter to [[Arjun Singh]], then Union Minister of Human Resource Development. In the letter, she stated that children in Class IX and XI, at whom the course was directed, do not require sex education as they are in the early stages of puberty. The state Education Minister Ghansyam Tiwari stated that they already had a [[life skill]]s course called Jeevan Shaili, and sex education will have a negative impact on young minds.{{cite news|title=Sex education course too hot for VHP|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/sex-education-course-too-hot-for-vhp-/29953/|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=3 May 2007}} ====Others==== * In 2016, a man was killed in [[Mankada]], [[Malappuram]], [[Kerala]] for visiting his girlfriend in the night. The victim was a 42-year-old man called Nazeer from the same locality. Around three am in the morning some of his neighbors spotted him in a house where a woman was living alone. They attacked him and killed as an act of ''moral policing''. Kerala police have arrested three persons in connection with this incident.[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kozhikode/Man-beaten-to-death-at-Mankada-moral-policing-suspected/articleshow/52953956.cms] * In 1996, it was announced by a Chandigarh-based company Global Internet Ltd. that an adult entertainment [[Pay television|pay channel]] called Plus 21 would be launched in India. In response to this, the [[National Commission for Women]] (NCW) filed a lawsuit in the Delhi High Court.{{cite book|title=Writing the Women's Movement: A Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Efv3V7Y9WzsC&pg=PA493|accessdate=26 December 2014|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Zubaan|isbn=978-81-86706-99-2|page=493}} NCW claimed that it was performing its stipulated functions of protecting the interests of women and preventing culture shock to viewers. NCW was represented by notable [[feminist]] lawyer [[Indira Jaising]]. NCW claimed that channel would be showing pornography which would violate Indecent Representation Of Women (Prohibition) Act 1986. The argument also cited the Indian Telegraph Act, 1885.{{cite book|author=Rupal Oza|title=The Making of Neoliberal India: Nationalism, Gender, and the Paradoxes of Globalization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Uz6tDR5L4gC&pg=PT82|accessdate=26 December 2014|date=6 December 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-08226-9|pages=71–73}} The High Court put an injunction against the launch of the channel.{{cite web|title=National Commission for Women|url=http://wcddel.in/ncfw.html|website=Department of Women and Children|publisher=Government of National Capital Territory of Delhi|accessdate=26 December 2014|quote=The Hon'ble High Court of Delhi put an injection on the launching of +21 adult channel by the Ministry of Information & Broadcasting, Govt. of India.}} * In the 2001, the [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Information and Broadcasting ministry]] banned two television channels TB6 and [[Fashion TV]].{{cite news|title=Centre considering ban on FTV: Sushma|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2001/01/01/stories/0201000k.htm|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=1 January 2001}}{{cite book|author=Comp. & Edited By Derek O'brei|title=Penguin Cnbc-Tv18 Business Yearbook 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QHrgZYS9fI4C&pg=PA140|accessdate=11 January 2015|date=1 June 2009|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-306570-8|page=140}} * In December 2000, after [[Priyanka Chopra]] was crowned [[Miss World]], beauty contests were banned in her home state of [[Uttar Pradesh]] under the orders of then Chief Minister [[Rajnath Singh]]. He claimed that beauty contests were against traditional culture and were vulgar. [[Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad]] praised the ban.{{cite news|title=Home State of Miss World Bars Beauty Pageants|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/dec/16/news/mn-1355|accessdate=24 December 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=16 December 2000}}{{cite news|title=Strange Homecoming: Miss World evokes an odd reaction: a ban on beauty shows|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/Strange-Homecoming/210657|accessdate=24 December 2014|work=[[Outlook India]]|date=8 January 2001}} * In 2003, Union Information and Broadcasting Minister [[Sushma Swaraj]] removed condom ads, funded by [[National AIDS Control Organisation]] (NACO), from public broadcasting channel [[Doordarshan]].{{cite news|title=Condom, Condemned Health experts are flummoxed by Sushma Swaraj's moral turn on AIDS awareness|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/Condom-Condemned/220387|accessdate=5 March 2015|work=[[Outlook India]]|date=9 June 2003}} * In January 2007, the [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Information and Broadcasting ministry]] banned the TV channel [[AXN#2007 AXN India ban|AXN]] for two months. The channel was allegedly adversely affecting public morality by broadcasting a show called 'World's Sexiest Commercials' after 11 pm.{{cite news|title=AXN banned for 'indecent' programme|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/AXN-banned-for-indecent-programme/articleshow/1260124.cms|accessdate=24 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=18 January 2007}} * In March 2007, [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Ministry of Information and Broadcasting]] banned [[Fashion TV]] for two months for broadcasting programs that were capable of corrupting public morality.{{cite news|title=FTV banned|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/ftv-banned/article1817756.ece|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=30 March 2007}} * In June 2009, the [[Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (India)|Ministry of Communications and Information Technology]] issued a notice to various internet service providers and directed them to block the pornographic [[webcomic]] called [[Savita Bhabhi]].{{cite news|title='Savita Bhabhi' is no more|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-savita-bhabhi-is-no-more-1269660|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=30 June 2009}}{{cite news|title=Govt bans toon porn star Savita Bhabhi|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Govt+bans+toon+porn+star+Savita+Bhabhi/1/50906.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=9 July 2009}} * In March 2013, the [[Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (India)|Ministry of Communications and Information Technology]] ordered [[Fashion TV]] to be taken off air for 10 days, for violating the Cable Television Networks Rules, 1994. The government claimed the channel was showing obscene and vulgar visuals which were unsuitable for the public and children. This was the 3rd time the channel was ordered to go off-air.{{cite news|title=Fashion TV ordered off air in India for 'indecent' visuals|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/fashion-tv-ordered-off-air-in-india-for-indecent-visuals/1094444/0|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=28 March 2013}} * In May 2014, the [[Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (India)|Ministry of Communications and Information Technology]] suspended the TV channel [[Comedy Central]] for 10 days. The ministry claimed that Comedy Central had violated Cable Television Networks Regulation Act, 1995, by showing shows which were obscene and denigrated women.{{cite news|title=Comedy Central banned for 10 days|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/comedy-central-banned-for-10-days/article4750821.ece|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=26 May 2013}} In November 2014, Delhi High Court upheld the government's order. By this time, the channel had gone off air for 4 days. They had appealed in the court claiming that their right to broadcast was protected under Article 19 of the Constitution. The court had also upheld a fine of {{currency|20,000|INR}}.{{cite news|title=No laughs for Comedy Central as Delhi High Court upholds Centre's ban on transmission|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-no-laughs-for-comedy-central-as-delhi-high-court-upholds-centre-s-ban-on-transmission-2038387|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=[[DNA India]]|date=25 November 2014}} However, later in the same month the Supreme Court stayed the order and allowed further hearing.{{cite news|title=SC stays Delhi high court order on Comedy Central ban|url=http://www.livemint.com/Consumer/FbPhn3NjhXkx9JhoLgESGI/SC-stays-Delhi-high-court-order-on-banning-Comedy-Central.html|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=[[Live Mint]]|date=28 November 2014}} * In March 2015, local authorities in the [[Malda district]] of [[West Bengal]] cancelled a women's football match, featuring national team players, between a Kolkata side and a North Bengal team in March 2015. The order came after Muslim residents and local [[maulvi]]s objected to women playing sports. Biplab Roy, the Block Development Officer (BDO) of Harishchandrapur, Malda explained, "When I came to know about the local opposition, I referred the matter to the [[Superintendent of Police|SP]] and the [[District Magistrate|DM]], and the local police station. The order came from the top that the match should be cancelled, and I acted accordingly in the interest of peace and tranquillity and public order."{{cite news|title=West Bengal: Mamata’s officials stop women’s football match after maulvis object to players’ clothes|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/mamata-banerjees-officials-stop-womens-football-match-after-maulvis-object-to-players-clothes/|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=17 March 2015}} ===Accusations of obscenity against actors and film-makers=== * In 1993, during [[Nelson Mandela]]'s visit to India, he kissed actress [[Shabana Azmi]] on the cheek. The incident created a controversy and drew criticism from the Muslim community.{{cite news|title=When a kiss means more|url=http://mg.co.za/article/1993-12-23-when-a-kiss-means-more|accessdate=11 December 2014|work=[[Mail and Guardian]]|date=23 December 1993}}{{cite news|title=Know what happened when Nelson Mandela kissed Shabana Azmi|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/know-what-happened-when-nelson-mandela-kissed-shabana-azmi-31180.html|accessdate=11 December 2014|work=[[India TV]]|date=7 December 2013}} * In 1995, a obscenity case was filed against model-turned actor [[Milind Soman]] and [[Madhu Sapre]] for posing nude in a shoe advertisement. They were acquitted by a Mumbai court in December 2009.{{cite news|title=Models Milind Soman, Madhu Sapre acquitted in obscenity case|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Models-Milind-Soman-Madhu-Sapre-acquitted-in-obscenity-case/articleshow/5279293.cms|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=29 November 2009}} The court said that what may consider obscene for one, may not be so for others.{{cite news|title=‘Tuff ad didn’t bring impure thoughts’|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-tuff-ad-didn-t-bring-impure-thoughts-1320879|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=7 December 2009}} * In February 2000, a Mumbai court heard an obscenity case against actresses, [[Pooja Bhatt]], [[Madhuri Dixit]], [[Mamta Kulkarni]], [[Karisma Kapoor]], [[Tabassum Hashmi]], [[Raveena Tandon]] and [[Juhi Chawla]]. The main complainant in the case was Archana Chavan, head of the [[Baroda]]-based Nari Shakti Sanghatna. She claimed that the actresses were corrupting Indian culture. The court dropped the case stating the allegation of obscenity were vague.{{cite news|title=Not guilty|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2000/feb/16obseen.htm|accessdate=11 December 2014|work=Rediff|date=16 February 2000}} * In July 2000, a obscenity case against Mamta Kulkarni was heard in a Mumbai court. She was accused of posing obscenely on the cover of magazine called [[Stardust (magazine)|Stardust]] in 1993.{{cite news|title=Cover girl Fundamentalist group in Mumbai threatens Mamta Kulkarni for wearing burqa to court|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/fundamentalist-group-in-mumbai-threatens-mamta-kulkarni-for-wearing-burqa-to-court/1/244501.html|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[India Today]]|date=14 August 2000}} The court fined her {{currency|15,000|INR}} however the judgement was quashed by the [[Mumbai High Court]] as lower court didn't have authority to levy fines over {{currency|5,000|INR}}.{{cite news|title=Mamta in a tight spot!|url=http://in.rediff.com/movies/2000/sep/07mamta.htm|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=7 September 2000}} * In January 2005, a case was filed against [[Pooja Bhatt]], the director of a film called [[Rog]]. The complainant was a St Xavier's College lecturer, Pratibha Naithani, who considered the posters of film obscene.{{cite news|title=Pooja Bhatt in trouble over 'obscene' poster again|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Pooja-Bhatt-in-trouble-over-obscene-poster-again/articleshow/7255253.cms|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=11 January 2011}}{{cite news|title=Hot Poster: Cops on Pooja's trail|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Hot-Poster-Cops-on-Poojas-trail/articleshow/992306.cms|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=17 January 2005}} The case was dropped in 2008 by a [[Bandra]] court. But it was reopened in 2011, after the petition of one Vinod Jain. In November 2012, the Bombay High Court dropped the case.{{cite news|title=Pooja Bhatt's fight for 'Rog' obscenity case continues|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/pooja-bhatts-fight-for-rog-obscenity-case-continues/448382-8-66.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[IBNLive]]|date=28 January 2014}} * In 2006, a [[Madurai]]-based lawyer, Dakshninammorthy, filed a case against actress [[Shilpa Shetty]] and [[Reema Sen]], under Section 109 of the Indian Penal Code, Prevention of Publication of Obscene Pictures Act and Section 3 of the Young Persons (Harmful Publications) Act. The lawsuit came in response to some photographs published in a newspaper called [[Tamil Murasu (India)|Tamil Murasu]]. The petitioner claimed that the pictures polluted the minds of the youth. The court had issued non-bailable warrants against the actresses.{{cite news|title=Arrest warrants against Shilpa Shetty, Reema Sen|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2006/jun/20shilpa.htm|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=20 June 2006}} On 23 April 2008, the [[Madras High Court]] dropped that case against the two actress, but however added that the case could be continued against the publishers.{{cite news|title=Case against Shilpa Shetty and Reema Sen quashed|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/case-against-shilpa-shetty-and-reema-sen-quashed/article1245418.ece|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=24 April 2008}} * In May 2006, a case filed against [[item girl]] [[Rakhi Sawant]] after a live-performance for "indecent behaviour" and "destroying public peace" under Section 110, 112, 117 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951. The organizer was also indicted in the case.{{cite news|title='Item girl' Rakhi Sawant booked for obscenity|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-item-girl-rakhi-sawant-booked-for-obscenity-1030327|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=20 May 2006}}{{cite news|title=Rakhi Sawant booked for indecency|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Rakhi-Sawant-booked-for-indecency/pmredirectshow/1540132.cms?curpg=1|accessdate=13 December 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=21 May 2006}} * In 2006, Shailendra Dwivedi, an Indore-based lawyer, filed an obscenity case against actors [[Aishwarya Rai]] and [[Hrithik Roshan]] for kissing in the movie [[Dhoom 2]]. The lawyer claimed that the scene was vulgar and couldn't be watched by Indian families.{{cite news|title=Obscenity charge filed against Bollywood stars|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/obscenity-charge-filed-against-bollywood-stars-1.625627|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[CBC News]]|date=3 December 2006}}{{cite news|title=The man who filed a case against Ash, Hrithik|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2006/dec/11sfa.htm|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=11 December 2006}} A separate case had been filed by a 'Dhoom-2'|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-court-summons-ash-hrithik-for-kiss-in-dhoom-2-1093329|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=27 April 2007}} * In January 2007, television.{{cite news|title=Activist seeks police action against Mallika|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/mal/20070104.htm|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=4 January 2007}} The men'|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/jan/10mallika.htm|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=10 January 2007}} However, later a [[Bandra]] court had accepted the petition.{{cite news|title=Mallika summoned in obscenity case|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-mallika-summoned-in-obscenity-case-1191496|accessdate=17 December 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=19 September 2008}} In June 2007, Narendra Tiwari, the President of the [[Baroda]] bar association, filed an obscenity case against her for the same performance.{{cite news|title=Mallika caught in another 'dirty' case|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/mallika-caught-in-another-dirty-case/31116-8.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=[[IBNLive]]|date=17 June 2007}} In January 2011, Sherawat was acquitted in one of the cases but Vinod Jain said that he will appeal in the Mumbai High Court.{{cite news|title=Mallika Sherawat acquitted from obscenity case|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/mallika-sherawat-acquitted-from-obscenity-case/743555/|accessdate=17 December 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=29 January 2011}} In the other case, '''Municipal disinvestment''' is a term in the [[United States]] which describes an [[urban planning]] process in which that a city or town or other municipal entity decides to abandon or neglect an unproductive zone. It can happen when a municipality is in a period of economic prosperity, and it seeks to improve its communities and infrastructure, and sees that its [[Poverty in the United States|poorest]] and most blighted communities are both the cheapest targets for revitalization as well as the areas with the greatest potential for improvement.<ref name="struggle">{{Cite book|title=Reclaiming American Cities: the Struggle for People, Place, and Nature since 1900|last=Platt|first=Rutherford H.|publisher=University of Massachusetts Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-62534-050-4|location=USA|pages=79–171|quote=|via=}}</ref> When a city is facing [[urban decay]], and has to compromise in allocating its resources, the poorest communities are the least profitable and investing in them seems unwise from a long term perspective, and so these communities are neglected as a matter of choice.<ref name="plague">[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN1859842534 A Plague on Your Houses: How New York Was Burned Down and National Public Health Crumbled] By Deborah Wallace, Rodrick Wallace. 2001. (Note: fire chief interviewed in the BBC-TV special "The Bronx is Burning," in 1976.) {{ISBN|1-85984-253-4}}</ref> Disenfranchised neighborhoods are slated for demolition, relocation, and eventual replacement. According to one view, disinvestment in urban and suburban communities tends to fall strongly along racial and class lines, and intensifies and perpetuates the [[cycle of poverty]] exerted upon the space, since more affluent individuals with [[social mobility]] can leave the disenfranchised areas.<ref>{{Cite book|title=the Social Control of Cities|last=Body-Gendrot|first=Sophie|publisher=Blackwell Publishers Ltd.|year=2000|isbn=0-631-20520-9|location=Malden, Massachusetts|pages=34|quote=|via=}}</ref> According to one view, municipal disinvestment is a direct consequence of local, state, and federal [[urban planning]] and [[urban renewal]] projects.
== History ==
=== The New Deal and the postwar era === Out of the [[New Deal]] came the [[Public Works Administration]], funding the construction of thousands of low-rent homes and infrastructure development. Meanwhile the [[Homeowners Refinancing Act]], as well as the [[Wagner-Steagall Housing Act]] three years later, provided generous incentives and reimbursements aimed at Americans recovering from the [[Great Depression]] who could not yet afford to invest in equity. In the postwar era, returning veterans were seeking homes to start families.<ref>"The House We Live In." ''Race: The Power of an Illusion'', episode 3, written by Larry Adelman, edited by Llewellyn M. Smith, PBS, 2003.</ref> There was a period of intense residential expansion surrounding major US cities, and banks were gratuitously providing loans in order for families to afford moving there. It is in this new economic landscape where [[redlining]], [[exclusionary zoning]], and [[predatory lending]] flourished.
The programs enacted during this time provided more displacement than they did replacement: the beginning years of housing and infrastructure development were defined by their clearance and destruction of communities.<ref name="struggle" /> The [[Housing Act of 1949]] increased the mandate for public housing, but in claiming to combat "slums" and "blight" the act was worded so vaguely that those terms could have been applied to most any post-Depression urban neighborhood. What was intended to rebuild in decayed communities was used against poor but otherwise flourishing neighborhoods by labeling them ghettos.<ref name="struggle" />
The [[Federal Aid Highway Act of 1956]] extended demolition of neighborhoods, with new roads cutting through the most vulnerable neighborhoods in order to create more direct arteries between the metropolitan and the downtown areas. The highway's construction expanded upon the already widening schism of urban poor and the suburban by further enabling [[white flight]] and reducing a focus on [[public transport]].
=== Civil Rights and the Great Society === During the postwar era, municipalities sought to grow enriched and modernized communities from the slums they demolished. As the Civil Rights movement was in full display through [[Highway revolts in the United States|highway revolts]] and [[Mass racial violence in the United States|responses to racial violence]], there was a growing mindset among urban planners that a communal-focused, people-first approach should be taken, along the same lines as community development handled by the recently-enacted [[Peace Corps]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|jstor=j.ctt13x0h4w|title=Thinking Small: The United States and the Lure of Community Development|last=Immerwahr|first=Daniel|date=2015-01-01|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=|isbn=9780674289949|location=|pages=150–170|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] continued the policies of his predecessor John F. Kennedy, and in the first year in office he signed into law the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]], and followed soon after with a series of bills that comprised the foundation of what was termed the "[[War on Poverty]]" and "[[Great Society]]", despite the protesting of a largely anti-integration Congress.<ref name="struggle" /> The new philosophy of the administration focused intently on [[Community Action Agencies]], fulfilling the demand from modernist social theorists and pouring funding and resources into volunteer forces.<ref name=":0" /> The direction of policy was seen as some as a form of direct investment in impoverished and minority neighborhoods, in contrast to the previous focus on new construction.
[[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] served as Assistant [[United States Secretary of Labor|Secretary of Labor]] under the Johnson Administration, and was a primary influence on policy development. Stemming from his controversial [[Moynihan Report]], many of the programs enacted within the War on Poverty intended to educate black and poor families in order to modernize their "culture." Government assistance, in the hundreds of millions of dollars, was intended for organic community growth, nurturing local governance, and a gradual transition from developing to developed urban regions. However, when shirking programs that were directly-run by municipalities, the money was diverted to smaller, unorthodox community action associations with unions or "social protest agendas". For example, it was an [[Office of Economic Opportunity]]-funded community center where the [[Black Panther Party]] started its development.<ref name=":0" />
=== Change in urban development policy === Johnson responded to the radicalization of Black Americans [[Watts riots|Watts Riots]] by ceding control of local OEO's to municipal authorities such as the mayor (a reversal of the original strategy of community-lead development) while funding was reduced and the practices of the offices and local community projects were more closely supervised.<ref name=":0" /> Moynihan was startled by what he perceived as the consequences of the War on Poverty and changed his philosophy and its practice under Johnson. He found the social policies of the past decades naive for trying to fix the "tangled pathology" he described in the white paper he authored for the US Department of Labor, ''The Negro Family: The Case for National Action''.<ref name="struggle" /><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moynihan|first=Daniel Patrick|date=1965|title=The Negro Family: The Case for National Action|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~mrosenfe/Moynihan's%20The%20Negro%20Family.pdf|journal=Republished by Stanford University|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> When the administration transitioned over to [[Richard Nixon|Nixon]], Moynihan remained as Counselor to the President, where he further pushed for dismantling the OEO.<ref name=":0" /> Though it continued to exist into the Reagan Administration, the OEO was put under the control of [[Donald Rumsfeld]] and [[Dick Cheney]], who more tightly controlled its function.<ref name=":0" /> It is during this time that Moynihan suggests to Nixon that Black communities be treated with a "benign neglect," a philosophy-of-action which would later be translated into the planned shrinkage policies of the 70s and 80s.
